On Feb. 9, 1948, Coleman was crossing the 400 block of West Brevard Street at night, when he was struck by a car driven by a Florida State University student, John H. Leonard. Coleman suffered a concussion, broken leg and other injuries and died nine days later. He was 63.

Leonard, from Milton, had been a B-24 pilot in World War II and was driving a car he borrowed from his aunt. Leonard, driving west on Brevard Street, said he was blinded by the lights of an eastbound car that pulled out from curb and said he didn't see Coleman until he was just 20 feet from the man. State attorney William Hopkins declined to press charges.

A month later, FAMU President William Gray announced the school's under-construction library would be named for Coleman. The $425,000 library opened Jan. 16, 1949. It was the first building on the FAMU campus to bear the name of an alumnus.

Tucker Hall named for FAMU's first president

Tucker Hall, the former home of Florida A&M's College of Journalism and Graphic Arts, is named for the university's first president.

Thomas DeSaille Tucker was born in 1844 in Sierra Leone; his mother was the daughter of an African chief and his father was an Englishman. At 12, Tucker was brought to the United States by a Methodist missionary. He earned a degree from Oberlin College in 1865 and taught school in Kentucky and Louisiana, before opening a law practice in 1882 in Pensacola.

In 1887, he accepted the post as president of the new Florida State Normal College for Colored Students. The school opened with 15 students in a single building on the site of today's Florida State University. Tucker and former Florida legislator Thomas Gibbs were the only instructors, charged with training Black school teachers. Under Tucker, the school grew to more than 200 students and eight buildings on its current site south of downtown.

Tucker resigned in 1901 following disputes over the direction of the school and his ill health. He practiced law in Baltimore before dying in 1903. Tucker Hall housed FAMU's journalism school from 1977 to 2005, when the college moved into an adjacent new building. Tucker Hall is now home to the College of Social Sciences, Arts and Humanities and the Charles Winterwood Theater.

Efferson Street honors FAMU dean

Efferson Street, a one-block long residential street off Gibbs Drive, is named for H. Manning Efferson, a one-time dean and interim president at Florida A&M University.

Efferson was a native of South Carolina who earned a master's degree from Columbia and came to FAMU as a math instructor in 1924. Efferson went on to serve as head of the math department, dean of liberal arts and dean of students before being tapped as interim president from July 1949 to April 1950, between the presidencies of William Gray and George Gore.

During his presidency, Efferson oversaw numerous construction projects, including completion of the former FAMU Hospital. In 1950, Gore appointed Efferson the first FAMU Dean of Administration. In 1954, the Pine Lumber construction company developed the Gore subdivision off Gibbs Drive just south of Tharpe Street. The company named the subdivision for the FAMU president, Gore, and its main street for Efferson. Efferson retired from FAMU in the early 1960s and died in 1972; FAMU named its student union building for him in 1975.

Efferson's daughter, Victoria Efferson Warner, was a prominent Tallahassee social worker, community activist and FAMU professor who founded the university's School of Social Work. Warner died in 2006.

Sellers Street honors dairy farmer

Sellers Street, a short, dead-end street off Pontiac Drive, is named for the late Calvin Collis "C.C." Sellers, a longtime Tallahassee dairy farmer.

Sellers operated a dairy farm from 1944 to 1954 that stretched from Paul Russell Road to Orange Avenue and included today's Leon County Fairgrounds. He and his wife, Mary, lived in a farmhouse that still stands at 1012 Paul Russell Road. In 1954, Sellers sold his land to Tallahassee developer Syde Deeb, who built the adjacent Apalachee Ridge Estates and paved a short street behind the farmhouse, which he named in Sellers' honor.

Sellers then moved his dairy farm to a 700-acre farm near Lake Jackson, operating it until the early 1980s. That farm, stretching from Old Bainbridge Road to North Monroe Street, encompassed today's Edinburgh Estates, View Pointe subdivision and Canopy Oaks Elementary School — and Sellers' two-story brick home was surrounded by the under-construction Arbor Landing apartment complex and set for demolition.

Sellers died in 1983; his wife of 47 years, Mary, is 97.

Wade Wehunt was city's director of pools

Wade Wehunt Pool in Myers Park is named for Wade Harrison Wehunt, the first director of city pools.

Wehunt, a native of Tate, Ga., came to Tallahassee in 1923. He was a real estate developer, who in 1929 built one of the early homes in Myers Park neighborhood (527 Oakland St.). He was hired in 1952 to oversee construction of the city's first three municipal pools, two for whites and one for Black residents.

After completion of the pools at Myers Park, Levy Park and Griffin Heights in 1953, Wehunt was named director of city pools. Wehunt initiated the first swimming lessons and first water safety classes and spent 20 years as director of the local Red Cross. He served as a city elections inspector in the 1930s and 1940s and spent more than 20 years as manager of the Elks Club (then on North Monroe Street where the Tennyson condominiums are today), where he was active in downtown affairs.

The Myers Park pool was named for Wehunt upon his retirement in 1968. He died in 1985.

Gallows Hill: Where FSU presidents reign from Westcott

Florida State University's Westcott Hall Administration Building, at College Avenue and Copeland Street, is built on a site once known as Gallows Hill.

The name stems from the fall of 1829 or 1830, following what is believed to be Tallahassee's second murder, when an unidentified Black woman was convicted of killing her baby and sentenced to die. The hill where Westcott is located was chosen as the site for the gallows and the woman was hanged there.

The site was used for subsequent executions until 1854, when Tallahassee mayor Francis Eppes built a male academy on the site as an inducement to legislators.

In 1851, the legislature had established two seminaries in Florida, on the east and west sides of the Suwannee River. Several cities vied to be homes to the seminaries: In 1857, FSU won out over Marianna and Quincy and opened its doors as West Florida Seminary — in the building on Gallows Hill — becoming the forerunner of today's Florida State University.

City's 'seven hills' just a legend

It is a local legend that Tallahassee was built on seven hills. That's why Seven Hills is a common Tallahassee descriptive name: Six current local businesses have Seven Hills in their name.

But it's a fiction: Tallahassee has far more than seven hills and none of them were ever identified as key to the city's location.

Some modern-day observers say "Seven Hills" was a conceit several hilly American cities adopted in tribute to Rome, which famously was founded on seven hills. Territorial Gov. William DuVal even named his Myers Park estate "Mount Aventine," after one of those Roman hills.

In 1997, Tallahassee Democrat reporter Jan Pudlow talked to city officials to identify the seven tallest hills in city limits: Goodwood Plantation (216 feet), Old Fort Park (212), Mission San Luis (208 feet), Old Capitol (207 feet), The Grove (204 feet), FAMU's Lee Hall (192 feet) and FSU's Westcott Hall (176 feet).

Ed Young, research supervisor for the Tallahassee-Leon County Planning Department, confirmed those remain the seven highest points in city limits — but noted there are numerous areas in northern Leon County with elevations as high as 248 feet. The National Weather Service lists Tallahassee's average elevation as 197 feet.

Orr Drive named for FAMU professor killed in WWII

Orr Drive, on the campus of Florida A&M University, is named for Herbert Roy Orr, a professor who died in World War II. The street runs south off Robert and Trudie Perkins Way, between the School of Journalism and Graphic Communications and Tucker Hall.

Orr was born in 1909 in Washington, D.C. He earned a bachelor's and master's degree from Howard University, where he participated in ROTC. He was hired at FAMU in 1936 and taught mechanical drawing and radio communications.

He joined the Army in 1943, became a captain in the U.S. Signal Corps and fought at Guadalcanal. He died in April 1944 at age 35 and is buried in a national memorial cemetery in Hawaii.

In 1938, he married fellow FAMU instructor, Ruth Bates. Ruth Bates Orr, who never remarried after her husband's death, taught 18 years at FAMU Developmental Research School and then many years in the Leon County school system. She died in 1989.

Ruth Bates Orr's niece is Carriemae Marquess, a retired FAMU food and nutrition professor (1946-1989), who was selected one of the top 100 FAMUANs of the 20th century. Marquess continues to live in the home near the FAMU campus that her aunt built shortly after World War II.

Calhoun Street honors senator and two-time vice president

Calhoun Street is named for John C. Calhoun, the 19th century statesman who played a role in Florida becoming part of the United States. Calhoun was a U.S. Senator from South Carolina and served as U.S. Vice President under two presidents, John Quincy Adams and Andrew Jackson.

In 1818, while Secretary of War for President James Monroe, Calhoun approved Jackson's invasion of Florida because of threats posed by Native Americans and runaway slaves. Jackson's incursion became the First Seminole War, and led to Spain selling Florida to the United States — though Calhoun later criticized Jackson for over-stepping his authority. Calhoun began his political career as a pro-Union supporter, but became famed for his defense of states rights, nullification and slavery as a "positive good."

North Calhoun Street has been on the National Register of Historic Places since 1979 for its 16 historic buildings. Calhoun Street was once mostly residential and lined with stately oak trees. The cutting of several oaks on Calhoun Street in 1940 led to public protest and the "Live Oak Trail," a driving tour of Tallahassee trees. In 1955, Calhoun (southbound) and Gadsden Street (northbound) became Tallahassee's first paired, one-way streets.

McLean Park named for former city commissioner

Jack McLean Jr. Park is named for a former Tallahassee City Commissioner who was instrumental in the city's purchase of the property in 1985. McLean was a city commissioner from 1984 to 1992.

McLean later became city attorney for Quincy and since 2008 has been Quincy City Manager. A native of North Carolina, who earned his law degree at FSU, McLean spent 17 years (1977-1994) as head of Legal Services of North Florida before beginning his political career.

McLean Park is set on a wooded, 52-acre tract along Paul Russell Road that was once the site of the John Barry Dairy. The dairy was purchased in the 1950s by developer Syde Deeb, who built the nearby Apalachee Ridge subdivision. Deeb gave the unused portion of the former dairy to the FSU Foundation, which sold the 52 acres to the city in 1985 for $425,000.

Southside Park opened in 1992, with hiking trails, ball fields and basketball courts. In 2004, a community center and two pools were added. The city commission renamed the park for McLean in 1998.

Gore led tumultuous era at FAMU

The Gore Education Complex at Florida A&M University, as well as nearby residential street, Gore Avenue, is named for former FAMU president George W. Gore.

George William Gore Jr., was FAMU president from 1950 to 1968, making him the second-longest serving FAMU president to J.R.E. Lee (1924-1944).

Gore, a native of Nashville, earned his bachelor's degree in English and journalism from DePauw, his master's from Harvard and his Ph.D. from Columbia. He joined the faculty of Tennessee A&I (today's Tennessee State University), where he became a pioneer Black journalism instructor, and spent 23 years as dean before he was hired at FAMU.

Gore directed a period of great growth at FAMU. More than 20 new buildings were constructed, including the FAMU Hospital (1950) and FAMU Developmental Research School (1957). Gore created FAMU's first university police force (1952), presided over the transition from Florida A&M College (FAMCEE, as it was called) to Florida A&M University (1953) and enrolled the first white student (James Van Matre, 1964).

But Gore's tenure is most remembered for the rise of student demonstrations. From the bus boycott (1956) to lunch counter sit-ins (1960) to theater protests (1963), FAMU students took a lead role in the Tallahassee civil rights movement. Under pressure from white officials, Gore discouraged political dissent by FAMU students and faculty but did not forbid it.

"He was not weak but cautious," said FAMU historian Leedell Neyland. "Gore's strength was that while he was not active in civil rights leadership, he did not prevent his faculty and students from participating."

After FAMU, Gore returned to Nashville, where he died in1982 at age 81.

Doug Burnette Park

The little park on Gaines Street at Martin Luther King Boulevard used to be one of the city's most popular children's playgrounds.

Built in 1938 by the Depression-era Works Progress Administration, the park was named for Doug Burnette, executive director of the regional Boy Scouts office and chairman of Tallahassee's first recreation board.

The park included a softball diamond, a basketball court, swings, seesaws and a tether-ball pole.

The playground equipment was removed in the 1980s. In 2008, the park was renovated with landscaping, benches and other improvements, including "Quark," an 80-foot-tall, blue-painted steel piece by John Henry, a nationally renowned sculptor. The sculpture was later moved to the Orlando Museum of Art.

DRS first named for Black educator

Florida A&M's Developmental Research School was once called Lucy Moten School, in honor of one of the leading Black educators of the early 20th century.

Lucy Moten was born in 1851 to a free Black couple in Washington, D.C. Educated in Massachusetts and Howard University, she was director for 37 years (1883-1920) of the Miner Normal School, a public teacher training institution for Black students in Washington, D.C.

She became nationally famous for her discipline and high educational standards, drawing Black prospective teachers from all over the nation. Moten, who never married, was killed after being struck by a taxi in New York's Times Square in 1933.

FAMU president J.R.E. Lee, an associate of Moten, named FAMU's teacher-training school for Moten in 1932. In 1935, a new Lucy Moten School was constructed at then Gamble Street and M.L. King Boulevard. Lucy Moten School originally served grades one through eight (then the highest grade offered to Black students), then was used for elementary classes when the school expanded to grades K-12 and was called FAMU High.

In 2009, FAMU High moved to a new complex at Wahnish Way and Orange Avenue and assumed the name FAMU DRS — though the historic Lucy Moten School building is still used for university office space.

Weems Road named for former cattle rancher

Weems Road, a one-time rural road that connects Mahan Drive to Tom Brown Park, is named for George Emerson Weems, a former state official who had a cattle farm in the area.

A native of Hillsboro, Tenn., and a graduate of the University of Arkansas, Weems moved to South Florida in 1914. He came to Tallahassee in 1933 as director of the newly created Milk Control Board, which regulated the state dairy industry (and was disbanded in 1969).

From 1935 to 1937, he served as the second director of the state Beverage Commission, established to regulate the sale of alcohol after the end of Prohibition (now part of the Department of Business and Professional Regulation). After he left state government, Weems operated a cattle ranch and livestock market on Lake Lafayette.

Weems died in 1958; his wife, Sally Hieronymous Weems, died in 1983 — the year Weems Road was annexed into the city.

Museum, school named for revered John Gilmore Riley

The school off Tharpe Street and the downtown museum are named for John Gilmore Riley, Tallahassee's most prominent early Black educator, community leader and businessman. Called Northwest Elementary when it opened in 1951, it was renamed for Riley a year after his death in 1954.

Riley was born into slavery in 1857 and worked odd jobs until landing his first teaching position in 1877. A self-taught educator, he taught in Wakulla, Gadsden and Leon counties before spending 33 years (1893-1926) as principal of Tallahassee's all-Black Lincoln High.

Despite never earning more than $100 a month as principal, Riley became one of Tallahassee's leading property owners and was revered for his leadership in the Black community.

The home he built in 1890 at 419 E. Jefferson is on the National Register of Historic Places and since 1997 has been the John G. Riley Center/African American Museum of History and Culture. (Feb. 6, 2012)

Goodbody Lane has a Thomas Jefferson connection

Goodbody Lane, a three-block connector street off East Park Avenue that borders the Florida Lottery, is named for Albert and Fannie Goodbody who once lived at the corner of Park Avenue and the dirt trail that became Goodbody Lane.

Albert George Goodbody was an English native, who served as a Tallahassee justice of the peace until his death in 1936. His wife, Fannie Maude Craig, was the great-great-granddaughter of U.S. President Thomas Jefferson and the granddaughter of Francis Eppes. Eppes was one of Tallahassee's early settlers, a longtime mayor and a founder of what became Florida State University.

As Frenchtown fades, mystery over name continues

Frenchtown is the name for the former commercial and residential heart of Tallahassee's Black community.

It was bounded roughly by Brevard, Duval, Call and Dewey streets, around the axis of Macomb Street's stores, restaurants and nightclubs.

Lore long held it was named for French farmers sent to Tallahassee by the Marquis de Lafayette in 1831.

Subsequent research revealed the farmers never actually came to Tallahassee. Frenchtown could have been named for Jourdan Frenchy, a mulatto carpenter who built many early houses there, or Frenchtown, N.J., site of an infamous War of 1812 massacre and stronghold of the African Methodist Episcopal Church, whose preachers often visited Tallahassee.

All but a handful of businesses have left Frenchtown, which is home to many new houses and apartments, plus the city's Renaissance Center.

Fading Frenchtown:Frenchtown fights to survive, preserve history as it's squeezed by student housing

Killearn Estates: Where Scottish and Irish eyes smile on Tallahassee

Most streets in Tallahassee's ground-breaking subdivision bear Irish names — even though Killearn is a village in Scotland. That dichotomy caused an early flap with the family who brought the name to Tallahassee.

New York financier Alfred Barmore Maclay bought a Leon County hunting plantation in 1923. Maclay planted thousands of plants on the plantation and renamed it Killearn Gardens in honor of his ancestral home in Scotland.

In 1953, his widow, Louise, donated the gardens to the state.

In 1964, Tallahassee native J.T. Williams began developing Killearn Estates — directly across Thomasville Road from Killearn Gardens State Park — and giving his streets Irish names.

Louise Maclay was incensed and protested the Irish names. Ultimately, the gardens were renamed Maclay Gardens.

Williams, who went on to develop Killearn Acres, Killearn Lakes, Golden Eagle and five Georgia subdivisions, laughs: "We always said we don't care if (the street names) are Irish or Scottish, if the check is made out correctly."

Hays Street: A name intertwined with history

This residential street that straddles Magnolia Drive from Belmont Drive to Oak Street, is named for Jesse Hays, who built the home on nearby Park Avenue that now houses the Florida Trust for Historic Preservation.

Hays came to Tallahassee at the turn of the 20th century to serve as manager of Tallahassee's first phone company; he was later a state inspector on engineering projects in the Everglades. In 1910, he and his wife, Sarah, built the Queen Anne style house at 906 E. Park Ave. Jesse Hays, who died in 1950, was an avid photographer and many of his photos of early Park Avenue are in the Florida Photographic Collection.

In 1949, son Harold Hays sold the home to Tallahassee insurance agent Buck Hood and his wife, Rebecca, who raised four children and lived in the home for nearly 60 years. Buck Hood died in 2002. Rebecca Hood sold the house to the historic trust in 2005 and died in 2009.

Saxon Street named for Capital City Bank founder

This long residential street through a traditionally Black community adjoining Florida A&M University is named for one of Tallahassee's most prominent early white businessmen, George Washington Saxon.

A native of Tallahassee whose education ended in grade school, Saxon began his business career as owner of a general store.

In 1889, he began a private bank in his store, and six years later (1895) he founded Capital City Bank, Tallahassee's oldest, continuously operating business.

Saxon was a prosperous real estate developer throughout Tallahassee (he donated the land for the Florida Governor's Mansion) and the Big Bend. He was among the early developers of St. Teresa, Lanark Village and St. George Island, which he owned from 1910 to 1921.

Saxon, who co-founded the first Tallahassee phone company in 1895, died in 1935. His numerous descendants include Tallahassee attorneys Duby Ausley and Palmer Proctor.

Easterwood served on city and county commissions simultaneously

Easterwood Drive, leading into Tom Brown Park, is named for Henry Grady Easterwood — the only person to serve on the Tallahassee City Commission and Leon County Commission at the same time. The choice is fitting: Tom Brown Park is owned by the county but operated by the city.

Easterwood, born in 1900 in Alabama, moved to Tallahassee in 1930. He worked 16 years for the Seaboard Rail Line then became co-owner of a furniture store. He was elected to a five-year term on the city commission in 1950, when the city commission expanded from three members to five members.

In 1951, Easterwood was one of three city commissioners who tried unsuccessfully to sell the city-owned electric company to a private company; the trio also fired city manager Malcolm Yancey, replacing him with Arvah Hopkins.

In 1954, Easterwood was mayor when he won election to the county commission. Easterwood's term on the city commission ended a month after he took office on the county commission, allowing him to serve on both commissions. Don Price (city commission, 1974-75; county commission, 1986-1992) is the only other person to serve on both commissions.

Easterwood served 11 years on the county commission, gaining attention for opposing the city's 1956 sale of Capital City Country Club to a private club to avoid racial integration. Easterwood died in office in 1966.

Opperman named for first College of Music dean, who inadvertently helped start the Marching Chiefs

Florida State University's 442-seat recital hall, Opperman Music Hall, in the Kuersteiner Building, is named for Ella Scoble Opperman, who created the modern day College of Music.

Opperman, born in 1873, was an accomplished pianist and organist, who earned degrees from Wesleyan College in Cincinnati and the Cincinnati Conservatory of Music. She spent three years abroad studying piano in Berlin and Paris before returning to teach music for many years at her alma mater.

She was hired as Director of Music at Florida State College for Women in 1911, and led the department from a program that conferred teaching certificates to a full degree granting program. In 1920, she was named the first dean of the College of Music and was considered one of the nation's leading music educators, before her retirement in 1944.

Opperman opposed the first efforts to form the College of Music's now-signature marching band. In 1938, 39 female students formed the Tally Troopers to march at student events. Opperman insisted they disband because she said marching was not ladylike.

Two years later, students resurrected the group, adding musical instruments. Though Opperman and the College of Music did not recognize them officially, the group played at school functions.

In 1946, after she retired, marching band became a credited class in the College of Music. In 1950, after the school became co-ed, the band was named the Marching Chiefs.

Opperman died at 95 on March 4, 1969 — the day of the infamous Night of the Bayonets, when armed Leon County sheriff's deputies lined Tennessee Street during a Students for a Democratic Society (SDS) protest at the FSU Student Union.

Adams Street named for John Quincy Adams almost was Palm Avenue

One of Tallahassee's oldest and main streets is named for the sixth U.S. President, John Quincy Adams.

Adams was President James Monroe's Secretary of State when Tallahassee was founded in 1824 and the city's two main thoroughfares were named for them. As Secretary of State, Adams negotiated the purchase of Florida from Spain in 1819.

Adams succeeded Monroe as president in 1825, when he became the only U.S. President elected by the House of Representatives because none of the candidates won a majority of electoral votes. Adams was defeated for a second term.

Adams Street was once lined with businesses and homes, as the street ran south from the Governor's Mansion, past the Capitol and south to the coast. All four Tallahassee City Hall buildings have been on Adams Street. The original police and fire stations and Tallahassee Democrat were on Adams.

In 1921, at the urging of Tallahassee Democrat editor Milton Smith, the city commission approved planting palm trees on Adams Street from the Capitol to the Governor's Mansion – and renaming the street Palm Avenue. Smith promoted the plan as Tallahassee's version of Pennsylvania Avenue in Washington D.C. Although numerous palm trees were planted, city commissioners abandoned the plan to rename the street in 1922, citing a desire to continue honoring John Quincy Adams.

Since 1927, Adams Street has served as the east-west dividing line for all addresses in Tallahassee.

In September 1972, Adams Street was permanently closed at Pensacola Street, as the new capitol was built on what had been Adams Street, ending its days as a main thoroughfare.

Ruby Diamond Auditorium named for FSU benefactor

Ruby Pearl Diamond was a Tallahassee native, who graduated from the newly created Florida State College for Women in 1905 — one of 13 graduates who made up the last co-ed class of the university until 1947.

She lived for 50 years in the Floridan Hotel on the corner of Call and Monroe streets (now the site of the Aloft Hotel). A longtime benefactor of FSU, she donated $100,000 in land to FSU in 1970, which named its auditorium in Westcott Hall for her — which was fitting as it was Diamond who, in 1936, suggested naming the school's administration building for Tallahassee native James Westcott.

The auditorium, originally built in 1911 and rebuilt in 1954, was closed for renovations in 2008. It reopened with a concert by blues great B.B. King.

Ruby Diamond died in 1982 at age 95.

Bull Headley Road named for pioneer of Killearn Lakes

Bull Headley Road, off Bannerman Road in northern Leon County, is named for Julien Christian "Bull" Headley, who once owned the 4,000-acre plantation that became the Killearn Lakes and Golden Eagle subdivisions.

Headley, born in Mississippi and raised in Kentucky, came to Tallahassee in 1946 to raise cattle and timber. In 1951, he bought Water Oak Plantation on the south shore of Lake Iamonia, renamed it Bull Run Plantation and built a home.

In 1952, Headley deeded a dirt road along the boundary of his property from Bannerman Road to Lake Iamonia to Leon County. The county named the road Bull Headley Road, though it was not paved until 1982.

Though generations of Tallahasseeans have pronounced the road as Bull HED-ley Road, the family pronounces its last name HEED-ley. Headley had five children with two wives; two of his daughters, Jill Poole and Kirk Headley-Perdue, still live in Tallahassee.

In 1964, Headley sold Bull Run to a group of Louisiana investors, who renamed it Kinhega Lodge and turned into a hunting preserve. In 1985, the investors sold the plantation to Killearn Estates developer J.T. Williams, who developed Killearn Lakes.

Kinhega, the name of a Miccosukee chief, is still used for the home that Headley built and for one of the two main roads in Killearn Lakes.

In 1959, Headley bought property in British Honduras, now Belize, where he raised cattle and timber on 18,000 acres. In 1962, he moved to Bermuda and split his time between Belize and Bermuda; Headley gave up his U.S. citizenship in 1972.

An inveterate entrepreneur who dabbled in many enterprises, Headley converted part of his Belize property to a resort in the late 1980s. Called Hidden Valley Inn, it had numerous waterfalls, including Belize's famous 1,000-foot Falls.

In 2001, Headley traded the waterfalls to Belize for more timberland. The waterfalls are now a national park.

Headley, the youngest of four boys, gained his nickname as a toddler, when a cow chased him and he ran into the house screaming he was being chased by a "Bull."

"Never was a nickname so fitting," said George Headley, the youngest of Headley's five children.

Headley died in Belize in 2003 at age 87.

Beard Street named for Welaunee Planation owner's granddaugher

Beard Street, a residential street by Lafayette Park, is named for Letitia Beard – granddaughter of one of Leon County's early prominent residents, Robert Gamble.

Letitia Beard owned 70 acres off North Gadsden Street between Sixth Avenue and Williams Street; the property had been part of the Lafayette Land Grant. In 1914, she sold the property to local developers, including Dr. Kent Johnston, who founded Tallahassee's first hospital on North Gadsden Street. Part of the property was developed as Meridian Heights subdivision (with a portion later donated for Lafayette Park).

Robert and John Gamble were were prominent merchants in Virginia. Their father, Robert, was a Revolutionary War hero; their mother was Letitia Breckenridge, daughter of a Revolutionary War general. She turned down a marriage proposal from explorer Meriwether Lewis to marry Robert Gamble.

In 1826, John Gamble moved to Florida and established Waukeenah Plantation in Jefferson County; a year later, Robert Gamble, bought adjoining property and established Welaunee Plantation in Jefferson County.

The brothers later moved to Tallahasseee, while continuing to operate their Jefferson County plantations. John Gamble was the founder of the Union Bank, with Robert Gamble serving on the board.

One of Robert Gamble's sons, Robert Howard Gamble, served as Florida comptroller after the Civil War. One of John Gamble's sons, also named Robert, established a plantation in Manatee County, which is now a state park.

Letitia Beard, named for her grandmother, was married to William Kelly Beard. Letitia Beard, 84, died in 1921 and is buried in Tallahassee's St. John's Episcopal cemetery.

Pond covers Coal Chute Park

A stormwater treatment pond built for the FAMU Way extension now covers the original Coal Chute Park — a historic longtime Black community park.

The four-acre pond is at the west end of Railroad Square arts district, south of the adjacent railroad tracks.

The park was originally known as Villa Mitchell Park, the name of the surrounding community. The original park had basketball goals and playground equipment. Children in the neighborhood played softball, basketball and football in the park, and it was used for community events.

In 1994, the city bought the park, fenced it off, installed new playground equipment and named it Coal Chute Park. Legend holds the area, once part of a sawmill, was where train locomotives stopped to take on water and coal – which was delivered through a chute.

The park was dismantled in 2011 as it and nearby properties were bought for right of way of the FAMU Way extension. Construction of the pond was completed late last year.

Villa Mitchell was the name of a suburban community developed in 1886 by C.L. Mitchell. It was bordered by Railroad Avenue, Gamble Street and the railroad in the large curve of the railroad before it crosses Lake Bradford Road. The streets were named for prominent figures of the day (President Grover Cleveland, Florida Gov. Edward Perry, Everglades developer Hamilton Disston). The neighborhood prospered for about 20 years. In 1891, Florida A&M moved to its current home on a hill above Villa Mitchell and the neighborhood became a Black residential area.

Once FAMU Way was completed, the park was paired with the Capital Cascades Trail, a pedestrian/biking path. The trail came to include a children's play area just east of the stormwater pond — replacing Coal Chute Park.

Apalachee Parkway named through a contest for original inhabitants

The Apalachee Parkway pays tribute to the first inhabitants of this area — and is the genesis of the names of the nearby city of Apalachicola and the Appalachian Mountains.

The Apalachee people occupied the area between the Aucilla and Ochlockonee rivers from the 1100s to 1700s. Famed as farmers and warriors, they were first encountered by Europeans during the expeditions of Spanish explorers Panfilo Narvaez and Hernando de Soto in the 1500s. The Apalachees lived with the Spanish at Mission San Luis from 1656 to 1704, before dispersing to Louisiana, where about 300 Apalachee descendants remain today.

The name Apalachee, from the Creek and Hitachi languages, has several interpretations. One interpretation is "apalchi" means "allies." Another holds it means "torch bearers" or "those who bring light." A third interpretation is "apalahchi," means "on the other side." The name Apalachicola joins "apalahchi" (other side) and "okli" (people), for "people who lived on the other side" of what is now the Apalachicola River.

Reports from the Narvaez and DeSoto expeditions indicated the Apalachee ranged as far north as the Appalachian Mountains, 350 miles from Tallahassee. So as early as 1563, Spanish cartographers were labeling the mountain range in today's Georgia and North Carolina, the "Apalachen Mountains."

Apalachee Parkway was named in 1957, after this newspaper sponsored a contest to name the newly constructed road. Tallahassee native Bill Yancey was one of seven people to submit "Apalachee," winning the contest because his entry was the earliest postmarked.

The parkway passes through the area believed to be Anhaica, the chief village of the Apalachees. The site of de Soto's 1539-1540 winter encampment among the Apalachees is one block south of the parkway.

TMH name salutes World Wars I and II casualties

Tallahassee Memorial Healthcare — which celebrated its 75th anniversary in 2023 — is named in tribute to those who died in World War I and World War II.

The city had limited medical facilities its first 125 years of existence: a church and a hotel during the Civil War; the Masonic Lodge for whites and a small clinic for Black people in the early 1900s; a private sanitarium on North Gadsden Street for white people (1924-1964); the FAMU Hospital for Black people (1950-1971).

In 1941, responding to a clamor from Tallahassee's then-17,000 residents, city fathers announced plans to secure grants and issue bonds to build a hospital. But after purchasing 15 acres east of downtown, the city's plans were put on hold by World War II.

In 1946, after the war, the Baptist Church began operating a hospital in the wooden barracks of an abandoned World War II military medical complex of Dale Mabry Field. But after struggling financially for two years, the church asked the city to take over the hospital.

In January 1948, armed with a $1.5 million federal grant, the city began construction on a five-story hospital at Magnolia Drive and Miccosukee Road. In April, 1948, the city took over operation of the Baptist Hospital at Dale Mabry Field, where it operated for 18 months.

On Nov. 4, 1949, Tallahassee Memorial Hospital opened as a municipally operated hospital. In 1976, the hospital converted to a private, non-profit corporation and changed its name to Tallahassee Memorial Regional Medical Center (TMRMC).

In 1998, for its 50th anniversary, TMRMC it restored its original TMH acronym by renaming itself Tallahassee Memorial HealthCare.

Carroll house becomes a iconic restaurant trifecta

Table 23 used to be the Front Porch restaurant and before that the former home of Chez Pierre Restaurant — though the tree-shrouded, two-story brick building at Thomasville Road and Sixth Avenue began life nearly 90 years ago as the home of Tallahassee businessman Fred Carroll.

Constructed as a one-story home in 1924, it was rebuilt as a two-story home in 1935 following a storm.

Carroll owned Capital City Ice Company, Capital City Bakeries, a Georgia fertilizer and peanut company and several parcels of local property. Carroll died in 1956 and his wife died in 1959. Son Fred Carroll Jr., and daughter Clara Jane Smith leased the building to a variety of businesses, including Bevis Funeral Home (1964-1968) and the Lt. Governor's Club (1993-1994) before selling it to Chez Pierre (1996-2012).

The two large oaks on the front lawn, the subject of some concern during remodeling efforts, were planted as saplings in 1936 after Thomasville Road construction had removed previous trees.

Live Oak Plantation Road named after governor's property

Live Oak Plantation Road, between Thomasville Road and Meridian Road, is named for the plantation established on its western end in the 19th century.

Most of the plantation, which once stretched all the way to Lake Jackson, has been subdivided into home sites since the 1950s. Originally, Live Oak was the 10,000-acre plantation of John Branch, a governor and U.S. Senator from North Carolina.

Branch moved to Tallahassee in the mid-1830s and served as sixth and last territorial governor before statehood in 1845. Branch's daughter married planter and merchant Arvah Hopkins, owner of Goodwood Plantation (and grandfather of the late longtime Tallahassee city manager Arvah Hopkins).

After Branch, it passed through many owners, including Dr. Tennent Ronalds, a native of Scotland, who built one of Tallahassee's first golf courses on the property in 1903.

Ruediger Elementary honors former teacher

Lillian Ruediger Elementary School is named for a former Tallahassee school teacher and Leon County Schools administrator.

Lillian Josephine Cross Ruediger taught at Florida High before becoming general supervisor of Leon County Schools from 1945 to 1951. Ruediger, who oversaw elementary schools, resigned because of poor health and requested a transfer to a teaching position at Kate Sullivan Elementary. But Ruediger, 54, died at Tallahassee Memorial Hospital on Jan. 16, 1952 before she could resume her teaching career.

Ruediger (ROO-di-gher) Elementary at 526 W. 10th Ave. was named for her when it opened Sept. 6, 1955, the same day Griffin Middle School opened.

Ruediger was a native of Lake City, who enrolled at FSU in 1922 but did not graduate until 1930. She was married to Julius Ruediger, a longtime superintendent of the city's gas plant. Julius Ruediger died in 1958; his son, Herbert Ruediger, a longtime city employee, died in 1978.

House built by Gov. John Martin marks site of earliest US Christmas

The chief structure at the De Soto site off East Lafayette Street — where Spaniards are believed to have celebrated the first Christmas (1539) in what became the United States — is the Gov. Martin House.

The brick, hunting lodge style home was built in 1934 by Florida Gov. John Wellborn Martin. Listed on the National Register of Historic Places, it is now home to the Florida Bureau of Archaeological Research.

Martin, a former mayor of Jacksonville, was governor of Florida from 1925 to 1929, presiding over the height and end of the Florida land boom. He spearheaded state highway construction and successfully advocated for a change to the state constitution to allow state funding of public elementary schools. In 1925, a new State Road Department building was constructed and named for him at 300 S. Adams St. — a building that served as Tallahassee City Hall from 1964 to 1982 and is the site of the current City Hall.

Martin ran unsuccessfully for U.S. Senate in 1928 and unsuccessfully for governor in 1932. Martin sold his Tallahassee property in 1941 and returned to Jacksonville, where he died in 1958.

Cobb named for principal

Tallahassee's first middle school, Cobb Middle School, is named for the first principal of its first elementary school: Elizabeth DeBerry Cobb.

Cobb was a native of Tallahassee who began teaching in 1915 at all-grades Leon High. In 1925, she became the first principal of Caroline Brevard Elementary, Tallahassee's first elementary-only school. In 1935, she became supervisor of Leon County Schools before leaving the school system in 1936.

Cobb went on to spend many years as house mother for the Ruge Episcopal Center at Florida State University and teach youth classes at St. John's Episcopal Church. In 1954, Cobb Junior High opened as Tallahassee's first junior high (now middle) school and was named for Cobb.

Widowed before she was 30, and affectionately known as "Bessie," Cobb lived most of her adult life in the Bradford-Cobb House at 403. N. Calhoun St. The home, in the Calhoun Street Historic District, was built in 1878-79. Cobb bought the home in 1921 and lived there until shortly before she died in 1974 at age 96. The home is now a law office.

Kate Sullivan was a teacher

One of Tallahassee's oldest elementary schools is named for Kate Sullivan, a beloved teacher in Tallahassee for 45 years.

Sullivan was a native of Tallahassee, who graduated from Florida State College, a forerunner of FSU. She taught many years at Caroline Brevard Elementary, the city's first elementary-only school, before retiring in spring 1948. In fall 1948, Kate Sullivan Elementary on Miccosukee Road and the now-defunct Wesson Elementary opened as the city's third and fourth elementary schools (after Caroline Brevard and Sealey Memorial).

Sullivan, who taught primarily English, was the favorite teacher of many students; a dozen prominent former pupils, including soon-to-be Gov. LeRoy Collins, were pallbearers at her 1953 funeral. Sullivan and her older sister, Mattie, neither of whom ever married, lived at 503 Beard Street.

Furniture from their home is displayed at Goodwood Museum & Gardens. The glass-doored bookcase Kate Sullivan used in her Caroline Brevard classroom is at the library entrance of Kate Sullivan Elementary.

Chapman Pond named for Justice

Chapman Pond is the two-acre city park and pond at Merritt and Circle drives in the Myers Park neighborhood. It is named for former Florida Supreme Court Justice Roy H. Chapman, who once lived nearby.

A native of Lake City, Chapman attended the University of Florida and Stetson Law School. He returned to Lake City and practiced law with Fred Cone, who later was elected the 27th governor of Florida (1937-1941). Cone nominated his law partner to the Supreme Court in 1937.

Chapman, who spent a term (1945-1947) as Chief Justice, served on the court until his death in 1952.

In the 19th century, Chapman Pond was one of three ponds on the Houstoun family's Lakeland Plantation. It was originally known as Wash Pond, because plantation slaves used it to do laundry.

It has also been known as Mosley Pond, DuVal Pond, Duck Pond and Sylvan Pond. It was named for Chapman on April 28, 1953.

Dorothy B. Oven Park

This seven-acre park on Thomasville Road just south of I-10 gained prominence in the 1930s as Camellia Gardens, one of the nation's largest commercial camellia nurseries.

The manor house was designed in 1936 by Alfred B. Maclay, creator of the nearby state park and gardens that bear his name. Maclay designed the house for Camellia Gardens co-owner Breckenridge Gamble, whose widow, Dorothy, married Tallahassee attorney Will Oven in 1960.

Upon Dorothy's death in 1985, Will Oven donated the house and heavily landscaped grounds to the city of Tallahassee, with the provision it be named in honor of Dorothy B. Oven.

A half-acre of the park houses a Tallahassee fire station. The house is used for meetings and weddings. The grounds attract thousands of residents at Christmas, when the park is decorated with holiday lights.

Carroll's Quarters named for Black female owner

The term "quarters" to denote housing dates to the 16th century and was most often applied to military and servant lodgings. In the American South, it became the term for slave housing — and, after slavery, was still applied to clusters of Black homes.

Tallahassee had numerous "quarters," including Gray's Quarters, Council Quarters, Henry Watson Quarters, Riley's Quarters and Collins Quarters. Some were named for the chief landlord of the quarters.

Others were named for the predominant Black landowner — such as Carroll's Quarters, in the area behind where Whole Foods Grocery replaced the Miracle Theater. Annie Carroll owned much of the still-residential neighborhood bordered by Thomasville Road, Pine Street, Ninth Avenue and Mitchell Street.

One of the landmarks of Carroll's Quarters was Oliver's Grocery at 1563 Pine Street, operated into the early 1970s by Alberta Oliver, grandaughter-in-law of Annie Carroll.

The cross street nearest the store is Gwen Street, named for Oliver's granddaughter. Alberta Oliver died in 2000; Gwen Oliver Parker, a TCC instructor, died in 2005. The former store was then used for storage by retired local football and track coach Billy Oliver, son of Alberta and father of Gwen.

Trimble Road named for hardware store owner who pioneered neighborhood

Trimble Road, which connects Tharpe Street and Hartsfield Road on Tallahassee's west side, is named for the late Jesse Trimble, a hardware store owner who built one of the first homes on the street.

Trimble, a native of Sandy Springs, Ga., came to Tallahassee in 1920 and worked many years as a bookkeeper and insurance agent. In 1944, he became a partner in Ralph Johnson's Hardware at 121 E. Jefferson Street (now the site of the House Office Building). In 1946, the two men built a new store at 1315 N. Monroe.

In 1956, after Johnson's retirement, Trimble moved across the street to a building on the southwest corner of Monroe Street and Seventh Avenue. In 1959, Trimble retired and sold his store to Nick Eppes and Henry Edenfield, who operated Eppes-Edenfield Hardware until 1995.

In 1948, Trimble built a home on 10 acres of a former pecan grove. In more recent times, the county graded the dirt trail from Tharpe Street to Trimble's home — with country road foreman Aubry Ott naming it Trimble Road. Trimble died in 1979. Since 1965, Jesse Trimble Jr., a retired Leon County Schools custodian, lived in the home he built next door to his father.

Appleyard Drive named for Confederate Navy man, newspaper owner

This westside thoroughfare that fronts now Tallahassee State College is named for Thomas Jefferson Appleyard, an early Tallahassee newspaper editor, printer and government official.

T.J. Appleyard was secretary of the Florida Senate from 1895 to 1905. In 1909, he became the state printer and also published the weekly Florida Record newspaper. During the legislative sessions of 1913, 1915, 1917 and 1919, he published the Record as the daily Florida Morning News newspaper. In 1919, he sold his newspaper to the rival Tallahassee Democrat but continued to operate a printing company, which was sold after his death to the present-day Rose Printing Company.

Appleyard, who joined the Confederate Navy at 12 and later was the major general of the Florida Division of United Confederate Veterans, died in 1931.

Wakulla County springs from famous spring

2023 was the 180th anniversary of neighboring Wakulla County, which was established as the state's 23rd county on March 11, 1843.

The county's name comes from its most famous feature, Wakulla Springs, which dazzled early Native Americans and Spanish explorers. Indigenous people called Wakulla Springs "Tah-ille-ya-ahan," which supposedly meant, "place where the water flows upward like the rays of heavenly light out of the shadow of a hill." But Spanish explorers named it Guacara, their phonetic spelling of a Timucuan town whose name they adopted for a string of missions in North Florida.

Guacara was pronounced Wakala by subsequent Native Americans (and later spelled Wakulla). Popular lore holds the name Wakulla means "mysterious waters." But experts have long dismissed that explanation as "entirely fanciful" — while agreeing the meaning of the original Timucuan town is a mystery.

How Martin Luther King Boulevard came to be

Longtime residents still occasionally call this "Boulevard Street," as it was known for 150 years. Legend holds it was named in phonetic honor of 19th century South American freedom fighter Simon Bolivar.

Others say it was named for its appearance as a heavily treed "boulevard" buffering the city's western edge (much as the downtown chain of parks buffered the northern end of town).

It was chosen for renaming in honor of the 20th century civil rights leader Martin Luther King, Jr. because it ran in front of Bethel Missionary Baptist Church, whose pastor, C.K. Steele, was one of King's lieutenants with the Southern Christian Leadership Conference. Because of protests by some residents, the name change came in two pieces, the south half in 1980 and the north half in 1984.
