Johnston Street inspired by service of sanitarium doctor

This one-block street from Thomasville Road to North Gadsden Street is named for Dr. John Kent Johnston, who operated Tallahassee's first hospital at 805 N. Gadsden St.

Johnston was a Tallahassee native, graduate of West Florida Seminary (forerunner of FSU) and co-owner of Tallahassee's first airplane in the 1920s with Ivan Munroe and Theo Proctor. The 12-bed Johnston Sanitarium opened in July 1924 and operated until 1944, three years after Johnston's death.

In November 1947, the building became the Seventh Day Adventist-operated Forsyth Sanitarium, named for Edna Forsyth, the Central Florida dentist who donated the $51,000 purchase price.

The Forsyth Sanitarium closed in 1964 and the building later served as the home of the Leon County Guidance Center (1969-1972), Apalachee Mental Health Clinic (1973-1986) and attorney offices. Since 1997, it has been the home of Moore Bass Consulting.

Pensacola Street one of our oldest paved roads

Pensacola Street, named for the city toward which it runs, is one of Tallahassee's oldest paved roads. It was originally constructed in 1916-1918, heading west from Monroe Street to near today's Appleyard Drive.

In 1928-29, with the creation of Tallahassee's first airport near Appleyard Drive, Pensacola Street was repaved and a bridge built over a swampy area that became the site of Doak Campbell Stadium (1950).

By the 1960s, the road had been extended to connect with State Road 20, which crosses North Florida from Palatka to Niceville (30 miles east of Pensacola). In 2002, the Pensacola Street bridge was eliminated with the re-routing of the street around Doak Campbell Stadium.

Pensacola, on the western edge of the state, was Florida's first European settlement (1559). But the city was abandoned two years later because of a hurricane, making St. Augustine (1565) the oldest continuously occupied city in the present-day United States; Pensacola was not re-established until 1698.

The name Pensacola is derived from a Native American tribe that occupied the area, the Pansfalaya, whose name meant "long-haired people."

Architect Phillips was eccentric mausoleum, clock maker; his skull is still missing

Two of the most interesting structures ever constructed in Tallahassee were designed and built by the same man: An eccentric architect named Calvin Phillips, who created the long-gone clock tower on South Macomb Street and a mausoleum at Oakland Cemetery.

Phillips was a famed New York architect who received a medal from France for designing buildings for the 1889 Paris World's Fair (whose most famous exhibit was the new Eiffel Tower).

In 1907, Phillips retired to Tallahassee, leaving behind a wife and two daughters in New York. By 1910, he had built a small home and 30-foot-tall clock tower at 815 S. Macomb St., earning a reputation as a recluse with a long white beard.

In 1919, he built his mausoleum, often sleeping inside the structure during construction. He died in November 1919; though his family never joined him, the mausoleum had slots for four caskets.

In the late 1970s/early 1980s, the clock tower was torn down by new owners of the property. In 2000, the mausoleum was vandalized and Phillips' skull was removed from his casket — and never recovered.

When Phillips died, the few Tallahasseeans who'd seen him described him as a lean man, with a white beard spiraling below his waist. He's inspired ghost stories as some have reported that a gaunt, spindly figure was seen perched atop the tomb.

John Knox: Presbyterian founder's name on short but major road

This major (if short) thoroughfare from North Monroe Street to Meridian Road began in 1958 as just a service road from Meridian Road to newly constructed Faith Presbyterian Church.

Church members named it John Knox Road, after the founder of the Presbyterian Church in Scotland. In 1964, it was extended down the hill to the area near today's Trousdell Aquatics complex. In 1971, during construction of the Tallahassee Mall, the road was extended to North Monroe Street, where it meets Monticello Drive and forms a major intersection.

The greatness of Gaither inspires name for multiple landmarks

It is the 30th anniversary of the death of legendary Florida A&M football coach Jake Gaither — for whom everything Gaither-named in Tallahassee (street, golf course, community center, FAMU gymnasium, etc.) honors.

One of six children of a Methodist minister in Dayton, Tenn., he was born Alonzo Smith Gaither. As one of the youngest students at Knoxville College, he was required to do chores for upperclassmen who inexplicably began calling him "Jake." The name stuck, with encouragement from Gaither because, "I liked the name Jake better than the name Alonzo."

A champion debater in college, Gaither planned to enter the ministry until his father died his senior year, forcing him to take a job as a teacher to help support his family. He taught at two schools before being hired as an instructor, assistant football coach and head basketball coach at FAMU in 1937.

In 1945, he became the FAMU head football coach — and led the Rattlers to greatness. He coached 25 seasons (1945-1969), led the Rattlers to seven Black national championships, three unbeaten seasons and a career record of 203-36-4. He was a three-time national coach of the year and was elected to the College Hall of Fame.

He staged annual football clinics at FAMU that drew top-name white coaches. He engineered 1969's FAMU-University of Tampa game, the first in the South to pit a predominantly Black school against a predominantly white school. He sent numerous players to the NFL, including Willie Galimore, Ken Riley and Bob Hayes. Gaither was famous for his oratory and lines such as, "I want my players hostile, agile and mobile."

Gaither died Feb. 18, 1994 at age 90. Sadie, his beloved wife of 62 years, died in 1997 at 92.

Hayden Road, home of Seminole football stars, was named for prof, wife

Hayden Road, an apartment- and condo-filled street overlooking Florida State University's Doak Campbell Stadium, is believed to commemorate a long-ago professor and his wife.

Edwin Andrew Hayden was a popular professor of philosophy and psychology at Florida State College for Women from 1915 until his self-inflicted death in 1921 at age 51.

Hayden dazzled students with his psychology experiments, but suffered bouts of depression and had a nervous breakdown shortly before his death. After his death, Hayden's wife, Clara, was hired as FSCW's chief library assistant, a position she held for 25 years. Clara, who never remarried, died in 1970 in the home on Pensacola Street she had shared with her husband and raised their two children in.

Hayden Road is the home of Burt Reynolds Hall, once an apartment complex that served as the football team's dorm from 1987 until a 1995 NCAA rule change eliminated athletes-only dorms. It is now set for demolition.

A new FSU dorm, for football players, Champions Hall, rose at Hayden Road and Belle Vue Way.

Wilson Street named for contractor, Lafayette Park builder

Wilson Street, which runs between Meridian Street and Miccosukee Road in the Lafayette Park neighborhoood, is named for William H. Wilson, a Tallahassee contractor and early developer of St. George Island.

Wilson was born in nearby Thomas County, Ga., but grew up in Tallahassee. In 1922, he founded Wilson Construction and Supply Company, which built many of the homes in the Lafayette Park neighborhood. In the early 1960s, he was a co-developer of St. George Island and helped push for the 1965 construction of today's Bryant Patton Bridge from the mainland.

Wilson built the first apartment house in Tallahassee, the Wilsonian Apartments, on a block bounded by Tennessee, Bronough, Call and Duval streets, which had been the site of the Leon Academy, a forerunner of Leon High. The site is now the City Centre parking garage.

Wilson also owned Wilson Beach Cottages at St. Teresa Beach, a complex of cabins originally built for World War II Army officers stationed at nearby Camp Gordon Johnston, which was a training ground for the D-Day invasion. Wilson died in 1969.

LeMoyne: An early French painter of Florida Native Americans

The LeMoyne Center for the Visual Arts is named in honor of France's Jacques le Moyne de Morgues, the first European artist to paint pictures of Native Americans in Florida.

LeMoyne came to Northeast Florida in 1564 as an illustrator and cartographer with the expedition of French explorer Jean Ribault. In addition to landscapes and maps of Florida, LeMoyne painted numerous pictures of indigenous Timucuans, which remain the iconic images of Florida's early residents.

The LeMoyne Art Foundation was organized in 1963 by four Tallahassee women: Nanette Fisher, Clifton Lewis, Mary Metzke and June Strauss. The foundation opened its first gallery in 1964 in the former Deeb House on the northwest corner of Calhoun Street and College Avenue (once a Po' Boys restaurant deck/parking lot).

In 1968, LeMoyne moved to its current home in the historic Meginnis-Munroe House at 125 N. Gadsden St.

Wesson started as school named for a mayor who offered Babe Ruth a job

The school district's multi-use R.N. Gooden-Nancy Russell Center at Wesson on South Meridian Street spent nearly a half century as Leonard Wesson Elementary, which was named for a former Tallahassee city commissioner and Leon County School Board chairman.

The school began in 1946 as Prince Murat Elementary, housed in the former military barracks of Dale Mabry Field. It moved in 1949 to 2813 S. Meridian St., and was renamed South City Elementary. In 1956, it was renamed Wesson Elementary, following the death of Leonard A. Wesson. In 2006, Wesson Elementary merged with Bond Elementary and its building was converted to the Gooden-Russell Center.

Wesson was a Tallahassee city commissioner for one term (1935-38), serving twice as mayor. In 1935, Mayor Wesson offered just-retired baseball star Babe Ruth the position as manager of the Tallahassee Capitals, a minor league baseball team (Ruth declined). Wesson served on the Leon County School Board from 1940-1947, including a stint as chairman.

Wesson died in December 1955, when he suffered a heart attack while turkey hunting. At the time of his death, Wesson was president of the local Coca Cola bottling company and had recently resigned as chairman of the state Game and Fish Commission because of health issues.

Once known as Bullfrog Pond and a place for baptisms, Lake Ella endures

Originally known as Bull Pond (and earlier as Bullfrog Pond), it was originally a natural lake used for baptisms, Emancipation Day celebrations and fishing.

In the 1930s, it was renamed the more pleasant-sounding Lake Ella by the wife of developer William Anderson, who developed the surrounding Anderson Heights housing development.

It remained a popular fishing lake into the 1950s and site of Tallahassee's annual Fourth of July fireworks into the 1970s.

Widening of North Monroe in 1968 led to pollution and it was retrofitted as part of the city's stormwater system.

Now officially known as Fred Drake Park at Lake Ella (Drake was a businessman and civic leader), the park has an encircling sidewalk, gazebo and aerating fountains and is popular with walkers, joggers, bicyclists and ducks.

Laundry owner, county leader lends name to Tom Brown Park

Tom Brown Park is 255 acres of former federal land given to the county in 1972 and named for County Commissioner Tom Brown, who had died the year before.

Brown served two terms on the County Commission and was a businessman who operated several laundries and a service station.

He also had a big background in sports: A former Clemson football star, he spent two years as the Leon High football coach and was a longtime Babe Ruth League baseball coach.

He was renowned for playing first base in city league softball games — without a glove. The county built the original part of the park, which is operated by the city.

As a fitting memory for a coach, Tom Brown Park features several softball and baseball fields, racquet and tennis courts, a disc golf course, a 3.1-mile-long bike and nature trails, and a fenced area for dogs to frolic.

Gibbs Drive and Gibbs Hall named for secretary of state who broke color barrier

A northside Tallahassee street, a Florida A&M University dormitory and a St. Petersburg high school are named for Jonathan Clarkson Gibbs, Florida's first Black Secretary of State, first superintendent of Public Instruction and a delegate to the state's 1868 Constitutional Convention.

Gibbs was born (1821) a free Black man in Philadelphia, graduated from Dartmouth College and became a minister in Philadelphia. After the Civil War, he moved to Charleston as a missionary to newly freed slaves.

In 1867, he moved to Jacksonville and operated a private school before becoming heavily involved in Reconstruction politics.

As Secretary of State (1868-1872), he conducted investigations into the Ku Klux Klan. He was elected to the Tallahassee City Council in 1872 and died in Tallahassee in 1874.

His son, Thomas Van Renssalaer Gibbs, was a co-founder of FAMU in 1887. The FAMU dorm was demolished in 2023 to make way for newer dorms.

Raymond Diehl: Pipefitter, liquor baron and developer

Raymond Diehl Road in northeast Tallahassee is named for Raymond Diehl Sr., a prominent businessman who built a home in the 1930s near the corner of Thomasville Road and present-day Raymond Diehl Road.

Capital Health Plan now occupies the site. Originally, the road was a dirt trail from Thomasville Road to near Centerville Road. Construction of I-10 in the early 1970s severed the road into the current two pieces on either side of I-10. Diehl was a pipefitter who operated a plumbing supply store then segued into real estate development.

After Leon County voters approved liquor sales in 1960, Diehl and his son, Raymond Jr., opened five liquor stores (later sold to the ABC Liquor chain). For 53 years, Raymond Sr.'s wife, O'Neill Diehl, operated O'Neill's Fairy Tale Shop, a popular children's clothing store.

In the early 1980s, Raymond Diehl Jr. and his wife, June, developed the Betton Place shopping center, where June operated the upscale Haystack clothing store for 17 years.

Raymond Diehl died in 1968 of a heart attack while hunting; O'Neill Diehl died in 1988. Raymond Diehl Jr. died in 2003.

Gaines Street and Gainesville named for famed Army general

Gaines Street, one of Tallahassee's most notable thoroughfares, is named for a famous 19th century U.S. Army general, Edmund Pendleton Gaines.

Gaines was born in 1777 in Virginia, where his great-uncle and his father were prominent in the American Revolution. As a young military officer, Gaines was responsible for surveying Mississippi and constructing the Natchez Trace road. In 1807, Gaines arrested former U.S. Vice President Aaron Burr in Alabama on charges of treason and transported Burr to Richmond, Va., where he was acquitted in a trial.

Gaines became a hero of the War of 1812, when he commanded forces that prevented the British from taking Fort Erie. He played a prominent role in the first two Seminole Wars (1817-1818, 1835-1842) and spent several years arbitrating disputes between white settlers and Native Americans. Gaines opposed removal of Native Americans from their traditional lands and gained a reputation for treating the tribes fairly.

In 1824, the first Florida territorial council to meet in Tallahassee made Gaines one of the first names attached to a Tallahassee street. Cities in Florida, Texas and Georgia were named Gainesville. Fort Gaines, a historic fort near Mobile, is named for him. Gaines died in 1849.

Coincidentally, Col. Edmund Pendleton Gaines (possibly a descendant), was the third of four base commanders of Dale Mabry Field, Tallahassee's World War II Army Air Corps base. Col. Gaines served at Dale Mabry from Sept. 1943 through June 1944 – gaining notoriety in October 1943 when he threatened to make Tallahassee off limits to military personnel because of an outbreak of venereal disease.

Venereal disease became a statewide epidemic in 1943, as Florida became the training ground for hundreds of thousands of military personnel. Gaines sent a letter to the city officials calling for "more aggressive measures to control prostitution and promiscuity." The crisis eventually waned.

State owns historic Brokaw-McDougall House

The Brokaw-McDougall House is the well-landscaped two-story home at Meridian Street and Miccosukee Road. It was built by pioneering businessman Peres Bonney Brokaw.

Born in 1814 in New Jersey to French immigrants, Brokaw arrived in Tallahassee in 1840. He and a partner began a successful livery business at Calhoun and Pensacola streets, which operated until the Civil War.

Brokaw built his home from 1856 to 1860 — a period during which he also served on the Tallahassee city council, Florida House of Representatives and Florida Senate. Following Brokaw's death in 1875, the house passed to a daughter, who married businessman Alexander McDougall (who, after his wife's death, married another of Brokaw's daughters). The McDougall descendants continued to live in the home until it was sold to the state in 1973.

The family's original 640-acre property, stretching a half-mile east along Miccosukee Road, once encompassed all of today's Leon High School property and was filled with crops and cows. Brokaw elaborately landscaped the area around the home — and according to unproven legend received advice from Frederick Law Olmstead, the landscape architect who designed New York's Central Park.

In 1998, the state leased the home to the city, which hosted weddings, receptions and art shows. In 2011, the state reclaimed the property to house its Division of Cultural Affairs.

Late Cherokee Hotel connected to Jim Morrison of The Doors

The 2012 pardon of the late rock singer Jim Morrison by Gov. Charlie Crist for a 1969 Miami conviction had many readers wondering: Where was the Cherokee Hotel?

"Room 206, Cherokee Hotel," was the address Morrison gave to Tallahassee police in September 1963 when he was arrested for disturbing the peace while a student at FSU.

As longtime residents know, the 4-story Cherokee Hotel was on the southwest corner of Park Avenue and Calhoun Street (across the street from the Knott House).

The Cherokee Hotel was built in 1922 and demolished in 1964. One presumes it was a temporary address in 1963 for Morrison, as the transfer from St. Petersburg Junior College looked for an apartment following the start of classes five days before.

Nylic Street an abbreviated named for business interest of Wadsworth's

Streets of a small enclave of rental houses and apartments near FSU are named for its developers — and an insurance company.

Howell Wadsworth, a Tallahassee real estate entrepreneur and insurance executive, once owned land at West Tennessee and Brevard streets, where, among other things, he was responsible for creating a housing development in the early 1950s.

The street that runs off Tennessee Street is named Wadsworth; another is named Hancock, for Wadsworth's development partner, Melvin Hancock. A third street is named Nylic, an acronym for New York Life Insurance Company, for whom Wadsworth was an agent for 40 years.

Wadsworth owned numerous tracts of land in Tallahassee, including parcels that include today's Riley Elementary School (for which he donated the land), Callen neighborhood, Fourth Quarter restaurant and a downtown square on Tennessee Street between Bethel Missionary Baptist Church and the federal building.

Wadsworth's late wife, Alice, was the sister of Florida Gov. LeRoy Collins; his son, Murray Wadsworth, is a longtime Tallahassee attorney. Howell Wadsworth died in 1985.

Gardens of Edenfield: A couple's legacy inspires road name

Edenfield Road, which connects Miccosukee Road to the Mahan Highway, is named for Lawrence and Isabella Edenfield – who became famous for allowing townspeople to grow vegetable gardens on their property on Edenfield Road.

Lawrence, a native of Grand Ridge, was a teacher and principal at several North Florida schools, then worked for the state Department of Education. Isabella was a native of Indiana, who taught at Leon High and worked for the Dean of Public Administration at FSU. They married in 1928 and had two children. In the late 1940s, the couple bought a 90-acre tract at the southwest corner of Miccosukee Road and Edenfield Road, then a dirt road.

Starting in the 1950s, the Edenfields began allowing needy FSU students and neighboring Black residents to grow vegetables in plots on their land. The Edenfields eventually expanded the program, providing space for professors, physicians, attorneys and other Tallahassee residents to grow vegetables. Lawrence Edenfield prepared and provided the land for free for many years (eventually charging a token $5 per row per year).

The garden program ended shortly after the deaths, just two months apart in 1979, of Lawrence (January) and Isabella (March). The Edenfields' farm house still stands, though it's now located on Berklie Drive — a name created out of the initials of the Edenfields, their daughter and son-in-law.

Mabry Manor has WWII street names

The streets of Mabry Manor are named for World War II generals and soldiers because it was once the home of Tallahassee's World War II Army Air Corps base — though the streets were not named for military personnel when it was a base.

Dale Mabry Air Field existed from 1941-1945. It occupied 559 acres bordered by present-day Roberts Avenue (on the north) and Mabry Street (east). The streets of the military base were identified by letters (Avenue C, Avenue D, etc.) and numbers (Third Street, Fourth Street, etc.). After the base closed, the land reverted to the city, which gave it to FSU, which used it as its West Campus from 1946 to 1956.

In 1952, at the request of the U.S. post office, the city gave the streets new names, honoring U.S. military leaders such as Dwight Eisenhower, Douglas MacArthur, Hap Arnold, Matthew Ridgway, George Patton, etc. Nininger Street was named for Army Lt. Alexander Nininger, the first World War II winner of the Medal of Honor.

After FSU departed, the former base became home to the Mabry Manor housing subdivision and Sabal Palm Elementary School. A short distance west, also off Roberts Avenue, is Seminole Manor, a housing development built by Syde Deeb from 1948 to 1950.

Duval Street named for man who set our capital status

This north-south artery in downtown Tallahassee, as well as Jacksonville's Duval County, is named for the first civilian territorial governor of Florida, William Pope DuVal (who capitalized the V in his last name).

DuVal had been a U.S. Congressman from Kentucky and territorial judge in St. Augustine, before serving as Florida governor from 1822 to 1834 — making him the longest-serving governor in state history. Under DuVal, Tallahassee was chosen as the capital of Florida, and DuVal lived in a home in today's Myers Park.

A colorful raconteur who ran away from home as a teenager, DuVal once shared a stagecoach ride with author Washington Irving, who recounted DuVal's adventures in a short story titled "The Early Experiences of Ralph Ringwood." DuVal moved to Texas in 1848 and died in 1854.

Red Barber Way honors voice of Dodgers, NPR

The street encircling WFSU television and radio studios, as well as a camellia garden in the downtown Chain of Parks, is named for legendary major league baseball announcer Walter "Red" Barber, who lived the last 20 years of his life in Tallahassee.

Barber broadcast for three major league teams, most famously the Brooklyn Dodgers, where he popularized such colorful terms as "rhubarb" and "sitting in the catbird seat."

After retiring from broadcasting, Barber penned numerous books, wrote a weekly column for the Tallahassee Democrat and appeared every Friday on National Public Radio's "Morning Edition," where he often extolled the beauties of Tallahassee camellias.

Barber died in 1992.

Bloxham gets park, street, building as governor who urged creation of FAMU

William Dunnington Bloxham was a Tallahassee native who became Florida's first governor to serve two times (1881-1885 and 1897-1901).

His most notable achievements were selling four million acres of the Everglades for $1 million to restore the state's financial stability and urging creation of what became Florida A&M University.

Bloxham died in 1911 and is buried in St. John's Cemetery. His one-time home at 410 N. Calhoun St. has been restored and is used for offices.

Bloxham Park is between Monroe and Calhoun streets in the Park Avenue chain of parks.

Bloxham Street runs between Gadsden Street and M.L. King Boulevard.

The Bloxham Building, in the 700 block of South Calhoun Street, is the former Caroline Brevard Elementary.

College Avenue originally called Clinton Street

College Avenue, the street that basically runs from downtown to the gates of Florida State University, spent nearly a century named Clinton Street.

Like many early Tallahassee street names, the name was applied at the time of the city's founding in 1824 to honor a national leader, either George Clinton, a U.S. vice-president under two presidents (Jefferson and Madison) or New York statesman Dewitt Clinton.

Though the original incarnation of FSU opened its doors in 1857, the street name was not changed to College Avenue until 1916. By then, the western end had been paved (1912), broadened from 24 feet to 30 feet and lined with oaks and stately private homes (since demolished or remodeled into businesses and sorority/fraternity houses).

Neamathla led tribe near Lake Lafayette

A residential street in northeast Leon County, Neamathla Trail, is named for the most significant Native American in Tallahassee history: Neamathla, who gave Americans "permission" to establish Tallahassee as the capital of Florida.

Neamathla was the chief spokesman for Seminoles in the negotiation of the September 1823 Treaty of Moultrie Creek, which attempted to relocate Seminoles in Florida. Territorial Gov. William DuVal praised Neamathla as "the greatest man you will see among the Indians, who controls his warriors with as much ease as a colonel his regiment."

Neamathla led the larger of two tribes occupying the Tallahassee area; the older Chefixico led the smaller band. Both tribes lived near Lake Lafayette, east of Tallahassee.

In October 1823, territorial commissioners John Lee Williams and William Simmons, met with Neamathla to tell him of the new territory's plan to locate its capital in Tallahassee. Neamathla objected but gave his grudging approval with the stipulation they not tell other Seminoles of his consent.

A year later, Neamathla threatened to make the streets of Tallahassee "run red with blood," unless the white settlers left.

search_result.title: Spring All-State High School Sports 2015
search_result.text:
The News Journal

The spring high school sports season saw its share of excitement, from Cape Henlopen winning its seventh straight girls lacrosse title to Appoquinimink winning the baseball crown for the school's first ever team state championship.

Behind those team achievements were great players. Let's take a look back at the most admirable student-athletes of the high school season.

Polytech girls lacrosse coach Lynn Richardson knew Ali McKay had the potential to score goals. That's why she moved McKay from defense to midfield before her sophomore season.

McKay was solid last year, earning second-team All-State honors. But this year, after some encouragement from her coach and teammates, she really turned it on. The junior led the Panthers with 104 goals, and was named the state's Player of the Year by the Delaware Girls Lacrosse Coaches Association.

"She's a well-rounded athlete, and she's a competitor, but I wouldn't say she is someone who is full of herself or overly confident," Richardson said. "We had to encourage her to shoot and drive to the goal."

Once the Panthers convinced her she could do it, the sky was the limit. READ MORE

GIRLS LACROSSE FIRST-TEAM ALL-STATE

Andrew Pettit had only one assist and no goals in his final high school lacrosse game.

But when it was over and Salesianum had secured a 12-2 victory in the semifinals of the DIAA Boys Lacrosse Tournament, the Tower Hill star was still the first topic of discussion for the Sals.

"We shut down Pettit," goalkeeper Ryan Kern said. "That was basically our whole game plan tonight, shut down Pettit."

Why would an opponent focus its entire defense on one man? Because Pettit finished his glittering career with school records for goals, assists and points, was a three-time first-team All-State selection and a two-time U.S. Lacrosse All-American. And this year, the Delaware Boys Lacrosse Coaches Association named Pettit the state's Player of the Year.

"What sets him apart are his stick skills and ability to create offense," Tower Hill coach Brad duPont said. "He has tremendous vision, and he knows where everybody is. He can put the ball on people's sticks."

He can put the ball in the net, too. And he can do it from any angle. READ MORE

BOYS LACROSSE FIRST-TEAM ALL-STATE

To hear Annie Jaskulski tell it, the most important tennis match of her high school career may well have been her first.

Strange when one considers she went unbeaten and won No. 1 singles state titles in each of her final three years at Wilmington Friends, including last month, the basis for a trio of Delaware High School Girls Tennis Player of the Year awards.

But that first match, as an eighth-grader playing first singles, set her priorities for her time at Friends and beyond.

"I lost my first match, against St. Andrew's," Jaskulski recalled during an interview at Bellevue Tennis Center. "I think it was 6-2, 6-3. It was the first time I was playing for a team. I was so disappointed; I didn't want to let my team down.

"I went home and told my parents that was the worst feeling ever and I didn't want to ever feel that again. I swore to myself I would never let my teammates down again." READ MORE

GIRLS TENNIS FIRST-TEAM ALL-STATE

Colt Williamson is on the road, a passenger in transit somewhere between Delaware and Maine. He listens on his cell phone, then redirects a question to his father.

"Do you have a claim to fame, Dad?" he says.

"Tell him you are" is the reply.

The subject is tennis, and for good reason. Williamson had just capped off his junior year at Milford High, having won the state boys singles championship. With his father, Rex, and "Pop Pop," Paul Williamson, coaching the team, Colt became the first Buccaneers No. 1 singles player to win a state title. Ever.

"That means a lot," Williamson said, " not just for me but for Milford finally having a state champ. Downstate, it's pretty much always been Caesar Rodney for as long as I've known. So, it's pretty nice to change it up a little bit and bring it to Milford." READ MORE

BOYS TENNIS FIRST-TEAM ALL-STATE

During a soccer game, Michelle Laz is like a shark.

Always in motion.

"I try to move around a lot," she said. "I don't stay stationary. If I see an open space, I quickly go there and call for the ball. Moving around is the best part of my game."

Laz found enough openings this spring to be named the state's Girls Soccer Player of the Year by the Delaware Soccer Coaches Association. The senior never stopped in leading Sussex Tech to a 13-4 season and a spot in the DIAA Division I semifinals.

Soccer is a long game, with a half lasting 40 minutes at the high-school level. Defenses threw everything but the kitchen sink at Laz, often shutting her down for long stretches. But more often than not, the end result was the same.

Late in the game, Laz would send a screamer into the back of the net, and the Ravens would celebrate a victory. READ MORE

GIRLS SOCCER FIRST XI

The high school golf season in Delaware can be boiled down to one event: The DIAA State Tournament.

All of the nine-hole matches held during the regular season fade into the background when the annual 36-hole test tees off at the end of the year. The golfer best able to handle the stress of the big occasion emerges as the champion.

For the second straight season, Salesianum's Liam Murphy passed the test with flying colors.

Last year, Murphy pulled away over the final nine holes at Dover's Maple Dale Country Club to win by four strokes. This year, the senior broke out of the pack again at Wilmington Country Club on May 26-27 to win by five and earn his second straight Golfer of the Year honor.

"There's really no better feeling than to be able to go in there and pull it off, and prove to yourself that you can do it," Murphy said. "All of those hours that you put in were worth it." READ MORE

ALL-STATE GOLF TEAM

In a sport whose defining adjectives are "faster," "higher" and "stronger," Ashley Bailey is all of the above.

Soaring 18 inches higher than any other Delaware girl ever before pole vaulted, excelling in five other events and leading her team to unprecedented success, the Middletown High senior won the Bill Thomson Award as the state's outstanding high school track athlete.

Just this past Sunday, Bailey vaulted 13 feet at the Junior Olympic Regionals at Stockton (N.J.) University, in a performance she would have undoubtedly reached during the high school season, but for the other work she had taken on.

Requiring speed, strength and jumping ability, the pole vault attracts the sport's most versatile athletes. But the compact schedule of a track meet prevents most vaulters from showing their skills in other events. Bailey, though, invariably performed in the maximum four events. READ MORE

ALL-STATE GIRLS TRACK & FIELD TEAM

If this decade has been a golden era for distance running, 2015 was platinum. Six of the top 12 milers in Delaware history competed this spring, five of them graduating last month.

In this elite field, Kieran Tuntivate dominated. The Harvard-bound senior broke the state records in the mile and 1,600 meters both indoors and out, became Delaware's third-fastest ever at 3,200 meters, set a school record in the 800 to clinch the Blue Hen Conference championship for Charter School of Wilmington and earned national notice at major invitational races.

In a year when Mykele Young-Sanders of Dover overcame mid-season injury to complete an unprecedented three-year sweep of the hurdles events and Jarod Wilson of Newark became Delaware's fastest half-miler in 30 years, Tuntivate earned the Tom Fort Award as the state's top male track athlete. READ MORE

ALL-STATE BOYS TRACK & FIELD TEAM

Regan Green's mother teases her, says her neck will get sore from watching the batters hit her pitches in college.

For four years, Green strained the necks of high school hitters as they watched her pitches scream past.

The Laurel right-hander left a trail of statistics and memorable performances that will become part of the lore of Delaware high school softball. A perfect game in a DIAA state final. Two state championships. A career ERA of 0.70, and a career average of 14.2 strikeouts per seven innings.

So even though the Bulldogs came up short in their bid for a three-peat, Green was a clear choice as The News Journal's Softball Player of the Year. The senior's contribution in the dugout was as important as her work in the pitcher's circle.

"I became a better leader on the team," she said. "You usually think of the pitcher as one of the leaders, but I had never really been in that spot because of the seniors that we've had. This year, I had to step up to it." READ MORE

ALL-STATE SOFTBALL TEAM

Brandon Walter allowed two earned runs in the first inning of Hodgson's season opener against eventual state champion Appoquinimink.

Then he allowed one more earned run – the rest of the season.

The 6-foot-2 left-hander put together one of the greatest seasons in the history of Delaware high school baseball, making him an obvious selection as the state's Player of the Year by the Delaware Baseball Coaches Association.

Walter's numbers bordered on the absurd. He struck out 147 in 72 innings, and allowed just 25 hits, 16 walks and three earned runs. The opposition flailed away to a .116 batting average.

"He was as dominant of a pitcher as I've ever seen, coached, been around," Hodgson coach Chris Moxley said.

He set a state record with six shutouts, threw a no-hitter April 2 against St. Georges and set another state mark with 19 strikeouts against A.I. du Pont on May 11. And he did it by consistently throwing the ball over the plate. READ MORE

search_result.title: Delaware club team to play for Elite National Premier League soccer ...
search_result.text:
The Delaware Football Club 2002 boys team competes with the belief it is one of the nation’s best soccer teams in its age group.

Now the side of 16- and 17-year-olds, most from Delaware high schools, has the chance to prove it.

On Thursday, Delaware FC begins play in the Elite National Premier League’s National Finals in Commerce City, Colorado.

“This is a big accomplishment,” said Delaware FC coach Erik Temple, a 2006 Salesianum graduate, “but something we expected ... It’s a huge event for sure but we’ve played in big games. It’s what we’re built for.”

Delaware FC has won big games, succeeding through a difficult regular-season schedule and then a rugged qualification process to get to Colorado.

“We’ve come together as a team and we just play and we win,” said center back N.K. Tima, heading into his senior year at Appoquinimink.

The 17 players include 12 rising high school seniors and five soon-to-be juniors. They represent 10 different high schools, including five players from Appoquinimink and three from Salesianum, winner of nine straight state titles and 14 in the past 15 years.

PLAY DAY: Youth soccer's opportunity on display at 76ers Fieldhouse

Tima is joined by Appo teammates Aidan McCade, the only player on the team actually born in 2003 instead of 2002, twins Cody and Colby Niggebrugge and Hindovei Tucker. Salesianum is represented by Nick Balbierer, Alex Krumenacker and Alex Whittaker. There are also two St. Mark’s players – Sean Lenderman and Michael Ranegan.

The rest of the roster is comprised of Alex Dolce (Unionville, Pennsylvania); Oryem Kilama (Wilmington Friends); Justin Lane (Wilmington Charter); Luke Nall (Kennett, Pennsylvania); Alex Romero (Conrad); Patrick Short (Sussex Tech); and Sam Teigland (Elkton, Maryland).

Despite that wide geographic base, “We’re a really close, tight group, so we all play for each other,” said Short, who has made a rapid comeback from a torn ACL, his second, suffered kicking for Sussex Tech’s football team in its season opener last September at Milford.

“We’re also very emotional,” added Short. “Each and every one of us wants to win. We’ll do whatever it takes to win. And then the team’s just tremendous soccer players, so when you put all three of those together it’s hard to beat us.”

Last year, the team finished third in its league and qualified for the U.S. Club Soccer Elite National Premier League Tournament in Lancaster, Pennsylvania. Delaware FC won that, defeating Philadelphia Ukrainian Nationals 02 Boys Black 2-0 in the title game on goals by Short and Cody Niggebrugge. It had beaten teams from Massachusetts, South Carolina and Ohio and tied a Maryland side to reach the final.

LATIN LEAGUE SPROUTS: Union's Fabian visits Kirkwood

This season has been even better.

In March in Richmond, Delaware FC captured the prestigious Jefferson Cup’s boys under-17 championship, winning its three games by a combined 6-1 over teams from Ontario, New Jersey and North Carolina.

Delaware FC then finished first in the East Coast Elite National Premier League, ahead of rival Manhattan FC.

That qualified it for the Elite National Premier League tournament June 28-July 2 near Chicago, where teams vied for spots in the ENPL National Finals July 11-15 at Dick’s Sporting Goods Park. Major League Soccer’s Colorado Rapids play in the main stadium there.

In Illinois, Delaware FC won group games against the Dallas Texans 2-0 on a pair of goals by Tucker, nipped the OC Surf of California 2-1 on two goals by Short and then handed Discoveries NPL of South Carolina its first defeat in a year on goals by Tucker and Nall.

That moved it into the championship round, where Short scored 15 seconds into the game and Krumenacker later added the game-winner in a 2-1 victory over northern New Jersey powerhouse Players Development Academy.

“It was really exciting, obviously something all of us wanted to accomplish but to actually do it,” said Short. “We put in the hard work all year so we had lots of emotional victories, but once we won it was super exciting."

MATINEE MEN:University of Delaware announces home football kickoff times

At the National Finals, Delaware FC faces Chicago’s Eclipse Select Thursday, Cleveland-based Impact United Friday and Gwinnett (Georgia) Soccer Academy Sunday in group play. The group winner faces the champion of the other foursome on Monday for the national title.

“It’s like a dream come true for the team and for me,” Tucker said of the team’s trip to Colorado. “I believe we are hoping for the best. We’re gonna play and show what we can do because I know we’re already the best so we’re just going to prove it.”

Representing tiny Delaware certainly provides additional motivation for his team, Temple said. But he added that Delaware FC’s success goes beyond soccer skills.

“Just the heart and the competitiveness. They want to be good and they train to be good,” said Temple, a Newark resident who is also an assistant coach at Neumann College in Aston, Pennsylvania.

“One of the unique things about this team is it’s very loose. But when the whistle blows, they’re 100 miles per hour, ready to go.”

David Baylor: DIAA leader

Baylor was hired in July by the Delaware Department of Education to oversee the Delaware Interscholastic Athletic Association, which regulates middle and high school sports in Delaware and operates its state championship events. Baylor, who had been serving as the DIAA’s sportsmanship committee chairman, is a Navy veteran who served 23 years in the Delaware State Police, was director of human resources and training at NKS Distributors, then became Delaware City police chief and then its town manager. He was also player development coach for the University of Delaware football team. Hired as University of Delaware football coach in December of 2021, Carty has guided the Blue Hens, the state’s most closely followed team, to two NCAA Division I Football Championship Subdivision playoff berths, its first in back-to-back years since Cary was back-up quarterback in 2003 and ’04. Pocomoke’s Jordan Becker has signed with the Baltimore Blast of the Major Arena Soccer League.

search_result.title: This Delaware city is said to have some of the kindest residents in US
search_result.text:
The residents of a community can make or break your experience in an area, whether they’re unwelcoming or quick to lend a helping hand.

A survey ranking the most “kind-hearted and helpful” residents in the United States features a Delaware location that may not be what you expect.

Kindest, most helpful residents in Delaware, U.S.

LuvLink, a business focusing on products supporting long-distance relationships, surveyed 3,000 travelers to uncover which U.S. locations have the most kind-hearted and helpful locals. The data was compiled into a list of the top 150 places known for hospitality and genuine human connection.”

Of the 150 places featured, Delaware’s contribution comes in at No. 149 with Wilmington.

While it’s not a quiet suburb or the laid-back beach towns that might usually come to mind when thinking about hospitality in the First State, Wilmington earns its place among the other locations featured. LuvLink cites Wilmington residents as being known for “their approachable and down-to-earth demeanor,” reflecting the city’s blend of big-city energy and small-town charm.

Travelers surveyed said Wilmington locals often help others navigate the city’s food and art scenes, offering tips about the hottest new restaurants and exhibits worth snagging tickets to. Those who have visited the city add that whether you’re downtown, on the Riverfront or somewhere between, city residents are enthusiastic about their area and friendly toward those wanting to maximize their time while passing through.

When the travelers surveyed were asked about the most memorable act of kindness they experienced in Delaware, 42% said locals offered them directions or assistance and 25% said that a local helped them during an unexpected situation or emergency.

Overall, 17% of respondents said they were invited to a local event or gathering, and 16% were offered a ride or were personally guided by a local. The 50-foot fin whale that beached itself at Delaware State Park on Sunday died overnight.

Marine Education, Research and Rehabilitation Institute volunteers and Delaware Department of Natural Resources and Environmental Control employees are working to move the whale to perform a necropsy to determine the cause of death, MERR board member Rob Rector said Monday morning. The whale will then be buried on the beach.

They can work only as the tide allows, Rector said, because the area of the beach where the whale died, just north of the Indian River Inlet, is a very narrow stretch. It's in the area where the ocean breached the dunes during a storm a few months ago.

The whale was an emaciated sub-adult, MERR Director Suzanne Thurman said Sunday.

"This is a species that lives way off the coast, so they would never come in near shore, except when they get too weak to be able to surface to breathe and their instinct is to get out of the water," she said.

Thurman hoped to at least sedate the whale, she said, but the water level made it too dangerous.

"With the water going around her, she can roll on us and we would be killed," Thurman said.

Reports of the beached whale started coming in Sunday morning. MERR, a Lewes-based nonprofit, responded to the area and set up a perimeter. Hundreds of people came to the beach to see the ocean's second-largest whale.

Many people even parked on the side of Coastal Highway and walked across the dunes to get a glimpse. The dunes serve not only as protection for the road but as a delicate ecosystem for wildlife.

"Delaware Natural Resources Police remind the public that crossing the dune to try and get a better view of the beached whale is prohibited and can result in a fine," department spokesman Michael Globetti said in a statement.

The last whale to beach itself in Delaware was in 2021 when another fin whale died at Cape Henlopen State Park. In that case, Rector said, the cause of death was intestinal parasites.

search_result.title: 2020 Democratic primary field puts diversity in spotlight
search_result.text:
JUANA SUMMERS and ELANA SCHOR

Associated Press

The early days of the Democratic primary campaign are highlighting the party's diversity as it seeks a nominee who can build a coalition to take on President Donald Trump.

Of the more than half dozen Democrats who have either moved toward a campaign or declared their candidacy, four are women: Sens. Kirsten Gillibrand of New York, Kamala Harris of California and Elizabeth Warren of Massachusetts and Rep. Tulsi Gabbard of Hawaii. Harris is also African-American. Former Obama Cabinet member Julian Castro, who is Latino, has also joined the race.

And on Wednesday, Democrat Pete Buttigieg, the 37-year-old mayor of South Bend, Indiana, jumped into the campaign. If he wins the Democratic nomination, he would be the first openly gay presidential nominee from a major political party. He would also be the youngest person ever to become president if he wins the general election.

The diversity is likely to expand in the coming weeks as other Democrats enter the race. The field that's taking shape follows a successful midterm election in which Democrats elected a historically diverse class of politicians to Congress, a pattern they'd like to repeat on the presidential scale. Neera Tanden, president of the liberal Center for American Progress Action Fund, hailed the Democrats' multiple trailblazing candidates for reflecting that "the central opposition to Trump is around a vision of the country that's inclusive of all Americans."

Joe Biden urges greater collaboration among political leaders

"A lot of different people are going to see that they can be part of the Democratic Party" thanks to a field that showcases women, candidates of color, and the first potential LGBT nominee, Tanden said. The primary "hopefully will bring a lot of people into the process," she added, recalling the high number of voters who engaged in a 2008 Democratic primary that featured a possible female nominee, Hillary Clinton, and the man who would become the first black president, Barack Obama.

The array of backgrounds was on display Wednesday when Buttigieg spoke in personal terms about his marriage.

"The most important thing in my life — my marriage to Chasten — is something that exists by the grace of a single vote on the U.S. Supreme Court," Buttigieg told reporters. "So I'm somebody who understands — whether it's through that or whether it's through the fact that I was sent to war on the orders of the president — I understand politics not in terms of who's up and who's down or some of the other things that command the most attention on the news but in terms of everyday impacts on our lives."

Gillibrand has put her identity as a mother at the core of her campaign, and Harris launched her campaign on this week's Martin Luther King holiday, a nod to her historic bid to become the first black woman elected president.

A number of high-profile candidates remain on the sidelines, including two who would further bolster the diversity of the 2020 field: Sens. Cory Booker of New Jersey, who is black, and Amy Klobuchar of Minnesota. Booker, who's widely expected to join the presidential fray in the coming days, visited the pivotal early-voting state of South Carolina this week for public events honoring King and private meetings with local activists.

Klobuchar is set to speak at the University of Pennsylvania on Thursday about her work on the Senate Judiciary Committee, where Booker and Harris also are members. The affable Midwesterner recently told MSNBC that her family "is on board" if she opts to run in 2020, though she's offered little clarity about her timetable to announce a decision.

Though Klobuchar would be the fifth major female candidate in the Democratic primary, female candidates shouldn't be shoehorned into a "narrative" dominated by their identity that excludes the policies they're championing, said Virginia Kase, CEO of the League of Women Voters.

Kase pushed back at one popular 2018 narrative in a recent interview, noting that "every year is the year of the woman — the reality is that we've always been major contributors" in the electoral process.

Rashad Robinson, executive director of the civil rights-focused nonprofit Color of Change, said in an interview that the diversity of the Democratic field is "a great thing and we should celebrate it," adding that, "Our work is always about changing the rules — changing the rules of who can run and who can rule and who can lead is incredibly important."

But in addition to those "unwritten rules," Robinson pointed to the urgency of changing the "written rules" of American life, adding that "diversity alone does not mean structures and policies and practices that have held so many back will change" overnight.

Meanwhile, three white male candidates who could scramble the race — former Vice President Joe Biden, Sen. Bernie Sanders of Vermont, and former Texas Rep. Beto O'Rourke — are still weighing their own presidential plans. Biden addressed a key vulnerability in his potential candidacy this week by publicly airing regret about his support for a 1994 crime bill that's had particularly negative effects on African-American communities, while Sanders built his own new connections to black voters during a trip to South Carolina.

Biden says he regrets 1990s crime bill, calls it a 'big mistake' at MLK Day event

As Biden mulls a run for president, his allies have been sending supporters a memo that could serve as a rationale for a campaign. The memo hails Biden's long track record in politics and argues that at a time of "unprecedented political chaos" during Trump's administration, Biden would offer "trustworthy, compassionate leadership."

O'Rourke, for his part, continues to gauge his own future amid pundits' criticism about blog posts he published during a recent road trip through multiple states. The 46-year-old Texan acknowledged that he's been "in and out of a funk" following his departure from Congress after losing a high-profile Senate race in November, sparking questions about the luxury of his indecision given the family wealth and network of passionate backers he can lean on.

As the Democratic field is poised to become more diverse, Republicans say Trump will run for re-election based on his record.

"The American people are better off now than they were two years ago because of President Trump's policies," said Republican National Committee spokeswoman Blair Ellis. "GDP and wages are up, unemployment has hit record lows, and industries across this country are thriving. These are the credentials the American voters want from their president and President Trump is the only person who can run on these results."

search_result.title: Tornado tourism? Storm chasing tours are popular and can be ...
search_result.text:
Pat Timmons has seen hail the size of baseballs and lighting storms that filled the sky. She faced wind so strong she could barely stand – and multiple tornadoes, too.

“My friends and family think I’m crazy but I’m having the time of my life,” the 76-year-old from West Des Moines, Iowa, said from a roadside stop in Texas where she was on her second storm-chasing trip of the year with Tempest Tours.

Timmons is one of thousands of people from around the world who flock to Tornado Alley to get as close as safety allows to the massive storms that wash across the American countryside from March through June. As climate change warms the atmosphere, the number of storms increases and the crowds are only growing.

There are over a dozen companies that run storm-chasing tours in the United States, a number that’s increased slowly but steadily over the past few years said Christoffer Björkwall, a Swede who caught the storm chasing bug in 2009 and now runs StormChasingUSA, a website that tracks tour companies.

That doesn't surprise Alan Fyall, Visit Orlando professor of Tourism Marketing at the University of Central Florida. Adventure tourism has been becoming more popular in the past few decades, and especially in the last ten or 15 years with the rise of social media, he said.

“It’s a bigger market than people appreciate,” Fyall said. “People want the thrill and the adrenaline rush.”

Storm-chasing tours are part of that market. They're not your typical bus tour – no visiting tourist traps for quick photos.

Most tour companies run between one to three small vans with perhaps six people in a van. They seldom have more than 20 guests per trip. The groups drive as far south as Texas and as far north as the Canadian border, chasing images on a radar screen and then patiently waiting for a storm to form.

"The guys will find us a high place where we can sit for half an hour and we just keep watching and photographing it," said Timmons.

Costs vary between $2,000 and $4,500 depending on how long, how luxurious and how many people are on the trip. The season typically lasts from April through August, though May is generally the busiest month.

Björkwall estimates between a quarter and a third of people who go on these kinds of tours are from outside the U.S.

“This kind of weather only exists in the United States,” he said. Add to that an excellent system of freeways and rural roads, accessible weather data and the endless vistas of the plains – it makes for a perfect recipe.

It's "something no other place has."

How safe are storm-chasing tours?

The National Weather Service is very much not in favor of the public going out in severe weather and would much rather have people stay safely at home.

“The NWS does not encourage anyone to pursue dangerous storms for any reason other than promoting public safety (spotting) and official research,” the agency says in a FAQ about severe weather.

But the agency acknowledges that despite the dangers, people do. So it cautiously suggests that tours are a better way of doing it. “Joining one of the professional tour groups is probably safer than going out yourself without appropriate training.”

Fyall says that's the trick of this kind of extreme travel. “The key with adventure tourism is to make it look as dangerous as possible but at the same time make it as risk-free as possible."

Tour operators are very clear that while there’s never a guarantee of safety, they do everything they can to keep their clients satisfied but safe, said Roger Hill of Silver Lining Tours based in Denver.

“Any time you’re around a severe thunderstorm, especially a supercell thunderstorm, there’s an inherent risk. You can’t keep anything 100% safe, it’s not possible. That’s why every tour operator has guests sign a waiver saying these are the potential dangers,” he said.

Tours offer long and detailed safety information before anyone even sets foot in a van.

“The first night they went over safety and how everything works, down to how to get in and out of the van and who has responsibility for moving the back seat so the last person could get out quickly,” said Samantha Ashby, 33, who took her first storm-chasing tour earlier this month.

And unlike in the movies, tours stay well away from the heart of the action. They want a vantage point with a vista, not a target.

“We try to position ourselves a few miles from the storm so we’re out of the way of large hail or lightning. And if a tornado forms, you always have an escape route planned,” Hill said.

If a storm starts getting too close, they move further away.

The thrill is not seeing things get destroyed, like in the movies, but to see something so powerful and beyond any human control, said Burns.

"The best storms for us are out in the middle of nowhere. They’re not going to hurt anything, maybe some fence posts some hay bales. But when it’s right in front of you it makes you feel really insubstantial,” he said.

But there are dangers. Quite a few years ago, a lightning bolt hit one of his vans, destroying it. But none of the guests were injured because the electricity went through the van and into the ground.

Surprisingly, the guests loved it. “About every one of those guests came back, they said it was so much fun,” he said.

A typical day on a storm-chasing tour

A typical day on one of the tours means driving hundreds of miles. They usually begin around 9 or 10 in the morning, after the tour guides have decided on a likely area for storms.

“The day before our chase we look at the data and make our forecast and then plan our logistics,” said Erik Burns, the owner of Tornadic Expeditions in Whitesboro, Texas.

Getting to the next spot might mean traveling halfway across a state and then setting up to wait for what might come.

Twisters get the press, but many tourgoers say that's not what ends up being the most awe-inspiring.

“We all come to see the tornadoes, but we go home in love with supercells,” said Timmons. These are enormous storms that can reach up to 10 miles in diameter and be 50,000 feet tall, according to the National Severe Storm Laboratory.

“When you get them in late afternoon when the sun lights them up they’re just incredible, they just blossom and grow. Sometimes they’ll be lightning and they get lit up from inside, they cover the sky,” she said.

Something else she fell in love with was seeing a part of the country most people never see. Despite living in Iowa, the tours have given her a new appreciation for the country.

“It’s just getting to roll down the road and just watch American small towns,” she said. “America is beautiful. We’ve met the kindest people.”

The danger of traffic

While being flattened by a tornado might seem the biggest danger, traffic is more of a threat, say tour leaders.

“The traffic issue has gotten horrible, there’s no question about it,” said Hill. May, which is prime tornado month, is especially bad.

“When we first started running tours in the late ’90s a lot of times there was no one else around. But now if you have a very significant threat area in Oklahoma or Kansas, every storm chaser or storm spotter or local resident is out there chasing. You can get a line of traffic that’s a mile or more long,” he said.

“It can be a little chaotic,” said Björkwall, who’s now been on 11 tours. “I have a friend who was in El Reno, the biggest tornado in the world, and he was stuck and couldn’t get out because there were too many cars on the road.”

Between social media, radar, weather forecasting and weather-sharing apps, hundreds of people can converge on an area where large storms or tornadoes are anticipated. Tour companies and news crews make up the smallest percentage of the cars on the road at that point, said Björkwall.

“There are thousands and thousands of storm chasers, that number keeps growing every year, everybody comes out on the Plains in May,” said Hill.

That’s likely to increase this summer with the arrival of a new movie about storm chasing.

New movie could increase interest

Hollywood plays a surprising role in the business of storm chasing.

Silver Lining Tours launched a year after the release of the 1996 movie “Twister,” about a group of storm chasers in Oklahoma.

“We really feel that movie started the storm-chasing industry,” said Hill, who’s been with the company since 2000.

In July, a new stand-alone sequel, “Twisters” will be hitting theaters and he expects an even greater surge of interest.

“People underestimate the power that the movies have in swaying people’s behavior. It’s a huge driver of tourism,” said Fyall.

If 1996's "Twister" was any indication, tour groups might see a flood of new customers come summer. But it's not clear there will be space for them. There are not that many tour companies and most of them sell out a full year in advance.

"We’re already 70% filled for next year," said Burns of Tornadic Expeditions.

Tourists can form bonds while storm-chasing

The experience was so profound that Ashby just finished a tour the first week in May and has already booked another.

Her group saw eight tornadoes in seven days, which was “incredible and powerful,” said the 911 dispatcher from northern Virginia.

“There were four guests in our van all told and we decided it was so amazing that we all wanted to do it again,” she said.

The tours for 2025 were already full so they had to schedule for 2026. “I’ve never planned a vacation that for out before,” she said.

“This was four people I’d never met before and now we’re going to spend 10 days together and do it all over again,” she said.

search_result.title: Michael Wardian runs across US in stunning ultra-running feat
search_result.text:
LAUREL, Md. — The skinny guy with the scraggly beard jogged north along the shoulder of the highway Tuesday, with the late-afternoon sun beating down on him and six strangers-turned-running-companions just behind.

It was Day 59, and Michael Wardian had run 44 miles in and around Washington D.C. so far that day — more than 1½ marathons. And he still had about eight miles to go before nightfall.

"I feel like I was made to do this," Wardian said with a grin. "This is my jam, for sure."

The 48-year-old from Arlington, Virginia, was nearing the end of a Forrest Gump-style feat – something that only the craziest ultra-runners have even attempted.

Since May 1, he had been running the entire length of the United States, primarily on Route 50, with the goal of finishing in 75 days or less. It's a journey that spans 3,234 miles, across 13 states, with more than 132,000 feet in elevation change.

And believe it or not, he finished significantly ahead of schedule.

STAY UP-TO-DATE: Subscribe to our Sports newsletter now!

On Friday morning, Day 62, Wardian dipped his toes in the Atlantic Ocean off the coast of Delaware, capping the longest run — and craziest adventure — of his life.

"I feel like it’s been 59 adventures so far," he told a reporter while jogging up Route 1, with a few miles still to go on Day 59.

"Every day I’m seeing new things, getting to have new experiences."

Wardian joins a group of fewer than 400 people who are known to have crossed the U.S. on foot, according to Jim McCord, who achieved the feat himself in 2002 and now moderates a Facebook group called USA Crossers. For comparison, that's fewer people than summitted Mount Everest last spring alone.

Wardian spent between 11 and 15 hours a day on the move, covering an average of about 52 miles — the equivalent of two marathons — before climbing into an RV for the night.

Sometimes, he had company — friends, fellow ultra-runners, weekend joggers who wanted to tag along for a few miles. Most of the time, he was alone. He ran through snow in Colorado, and a heat index of 110 degrees in southern Illinois. He listened to an estimated 35 audiobooks, most at two-times speed. He went through three pairs of Hoka running shoes. He lost at least 12 pounds.

"It takes a lot of grit," said crew chief Eric Belz, who's been driving the RV and supporting Wardian throughout his journey. "And a lot of passion."

A former Michigan State lacrosse player, Wardian is an international ship broker by trade but has become a well-known figure in the ultra-running community over the years. He has run seven marathons on seven continents in seven days, and previously held the world record for fastest marathons on a treadmill and while pushing a stroller.

He described this transcontinental run (inspired, yes, by Forrest Gump) as a long-held dream — something he'd thought about for decades, but always put off for one reason or another. Then, in 2020, he started dealing with herniated discs in his back and wondered if he'd ever be able to run long distances again.

"It was really humbling," Wardian said. "You always think you have more time."

The injury, he said, was a spark. With the support of his wife, Jennifer, and their two teenage boys, Wardian connected with Belz, who had previously helped ultramarathoner Karl Meltzer run the Appalachian Trail in record time in 2016.

Together, they mapped out a route along Route 50, with the expected starting and stopping points for each day. They rented an RV and stocked up on supplies. And Wardian decided to use the trip as a way to raise money for the charitable organization World Vision, helping families around the world get access to clean drinking water. (By Thursday night, he had exceeded his $100,000 goal.)

Then, starting on the steps of city hall in San Francisco on May 1, Wardian hit the road. In a strange twist, his first six miles were actually in the opposite direction, to touch the ocean. He's been running east ever since.

"It’s been a wild ride," said Belz, 44. "Six miles up the road, where I’m going to crew Mike, I really don’t know what’s up there yet. So it’s just the excitement of: What’s down the road for us?”

On Day 38, for example, Wardian said he was jogging through western Missouri with a few others when a stray retriever started running alongside them. They called the dog "Yellow," and it joined them for the next 40 miles.

On Day 46, on the way from Illinois to Indiana, a woman saw Wardian walking alone on the side of the highway and stopped to offer him a ride in her mini-van. He explained that he was running across the country, and politely declined. She then came back a few minutes later, just to be sure. "I wouldn't tell anyone, (that) I gave you a ride," she said.

On Day 51, Wardian said, someone threw a half-eaten hamburger at him.

"It missed me and hit the girl I was running with right in the chest," he said. "Yeah, it was pretty gross."

Wardian admitted he's been discouraged at times by the lack of sidewalks along his route, the drivers who have rolled down their windows to call him an idiot, the truckers who have tried to nudge him off the road.

But the overwhelming feeling, he said, is gratitude — for those who have joined him along the way, and for the beauty of the country.

"I’m so Team America right now," he said. "For all the negative stuff, this country is super special. And there’s beauty everywhere.

"People talk about 'flyover country.' Some of the most beautiful places I saw were in the middle of America, and some of the kindest people."

Through it all, Belz said he's been impressed by Wardian's consistency and good spirits – his frequent desire to add a few more miles to the day, even after he's run 50.

James Hale, a 42-year-old ultra-runner from Catonsville, Maryland, marveled at the mental fortitude it takes to complete such a trek — on top of all the aches and pains.

"Even most ultra-runners can’t do this in a day, at his pace," said Hale, who joined Wardian for the second half of his run Tuesday. "He’s sort of that superhuman that can just move."

Wardian, who lives less than a mile off Route 50 in Arlington, ran through his neighborhood Tuesday morning before continuing on. He said he's already got a few bike races on his schedule, after his run across the country ends — as well as dreams of eventually becoming a professional pickleball player and climbing Mount Everest.

On this day, though, it was more miles along the side of the highway — north toward Baltimore, then east toward the Atlantic Ocean. He said he's been dealing with "some pretty big blisters" in recent weeks, but otherwise felt great.

"I feel like I could do this every day until the end of time, right now," Wardian said.

search_result.title: Wilmington pastor seeks knowledge on the streets
search_result.text:
Esteban Parra

The News Journal

WILMINGTON The Rev. Fredrick Allen admits he was nervous and fearful when he walked out of his city home last week to spend a week on the street learning more about the people he serves – the homeless. Yet he quickly realized that he was not nearly as frightened as the hundreds of people here who find themselves without shelter and food.

"How can I help somebody if I really don't know their struggle," asked Allen as he stood outside Wilmington's Friendship House Men's Day Center with other homeless people last week. The 47-year-old nondenominational minister looked tired as he clutched his backpack, four days into his weeklong quest.

"It a strain out here. I'm physically drained. It beats you up."

Most homeless people are willing to help one another, Allen said, and most are willing to share what little food they have. The pastor, who did not identify himself during the weeklong experiment that ended Saturday, said he now understands what the homeless mean when they speak of being exhausted all the time: Because they constantly fear being robbed or attacked, most take only cat naps. Sleep deprivation is a part of life.

Through his urban ministry, Allen wants to use the new insight gained to speak for the voiceless living on the streets. According to the Homeless Planning Council of Delaware's point-in-time survey, the state's homeless problem has remained steady over the last few years at less than 1,000 people. Last year's count found 950 people experiencing homelessness.

"I decided I wanted to know exactly what they feel like because giving food to someone is just helping them one day," he said. "We [homeless advocacy groups] see them once a week. We feed them and we think we are doing some good for them.

"But that's just us feeling great about helping them. They need more help than that. Some of them want to be here, and some of them don't want to be here. Some of them really need help."

Allen's method was applauded by some homeless advocates.

"It's a great idea to be able to have somebody that actually has a little bit of experience to be able to talk about this," said Allen Conover, chief executive of the Rick VanStory Resource Center, a drop-in center that offers support for those with psychiatric disorders.

A homeless week recorded on social media

Not only is Allen learning more about this community, but his stories can help teach other providers about a community often shunned by society. Conover said explaining how helpful homeless people are to one another would go a long way to de-stigmatize this population.

During his time on the street, several homeless men tried to help him survive, he said. One loaned him water shoes for a mandatory shower at the Sunday Breakfast Mission; another gave him a soda and a lesson on making ends meet. Allen said he cried when a homeless man insisted on sharing his only meal with him.

"People without houses are the most kindest people I've ever met in my life. It's amazing," said Conover, noting that he, too, has witnessed acts of kindness such as a homeless man helping others get socks. "I've seen that happen on numerous occasions."

"What he did was try to get to the bottom of what people need," Conover said.

While Allen's journey helped give him insight into what homeless people experience, Cathy McKay, president and chief executive officer of Connections Community Support Programs, said his journey doesn't explain why people are homeless. There are many reasons — including employed people living paycheck-to-paychek who don't have a support system in times of crisis.

"Sleeping on the street is one thing," she said. "But really understanding that there are people sleeping on the street who are really in bad shape and they need help right away. I don't know for sure that you can replicate that."

Allen didn't tell people on the street why he was out there. Instead he talked, listened and observed. And while there were days he almost quit and went home to his comfortable bed, Allen said he was pushed to finish the seven-day quest because he knew others didn't have his option. Without direction, he said, it's easy to feel hopeless.

"I can just imagine how they must feel because they have to live this every day," he said. "Because there is nothing to do, but wait and wait and just hope that someone will help."

Since returning home this week, Allen has begun helping three men he met during his weeklong journey — counseling them on what services that could help them get back on their feet. Allen is helping one man who lost his identification get documents to get Social Security card reissued, and to get a new driver's license.

Once these men have re-established themselves, Allen wants each of them to go back into the homeless community and help three more people. He hopes this can become an ongoing cycle.

"That's the commitment I'm asking for," he said. "I'm not asking them to give me anything. I just want them to go back and give other people hope."
