search_result.title: CDC intervention plan for Wilmington teen violence lacks political will
search_result.text:
Sidewalk memorials of teddy bears, candles and photographs dot Wilmington's poorest neighborhoods, reminding residents of teens who have fallen to gun violence.

Families struggle to raise money to bury their children. Cries for justice go unanswered.

The constant crackle of gunfire makes longtime residents feel as if the city has abandoned them. Yet some teens act as if it can't touch them.

"There are only two roads that this (violence) leads to — death and prison," said the Rev. Donald Morton, a Wilmington pastor and executive director of the Complexities of Color Coalition, a grassroots effort to address racial oppression. "And both of those roads, the young people are not afraid of. It just doesn't matter to them anymore."

About 41,000 of Wilmington's nearly 72,000 residents are African-American, as are most suspects and victims of gun violence. At the end of August, 43 of the last 50 homicide victims in the city were black.

Morton and others said political, religious and law enforcement leaders must own the ongoing bloodbath — and plot a course to correct it.

"The failure is ours," added Morton, pastor of the Tabernacle Full Gospel Baptist Church, "on individuals that have let this go too long hoping this would self-correct.”

In 2013, Wilmington City Councilwoman Hanifa Shabazz asked the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention to study gun violence as a public health epidemic – a new undertaking for the agency, which normally uses its investigative teams to determine whether environmental factors are causing health issues such as cancer clusters.

The CDC provided Wilmington with a one-of-a-kind prescription to quell the shootings in its 2015 report, noting that Delaware's largest city experienced "epidemic levels of urban gun violence."

But no local or state dollars have been allocated to implement the key component of the CDC roadmap: Use data such as truancy records, emergency room visits and domestic abuse allegations to identify at-risk children, and intervene in their lives early — while in elementary and middle school — when the information signals a potentially life-alerting alarm.

Interactive Map:Explore Wilmington shootings

The CDC also said Delaware must provide these children with life-skills programs and relationships to serve as a foundation for their future. Mentorships and smart programming could help more children turn their lives around, stay out of prison and survive, the agency said.

No money was allocated by former Wilmington Mayor Dennis P. Williams or former Gov. Jack Markell. And newly elected leaders Mayor Mike Purzycki and Gov. John Carney have yet to put any money behind the CDC's data-focused road map.

In interviews with The News Journal, Carney acknowledged that the data plan was a state responsibility, but said he would not allocate more state dollars for the city until he was assured all expenditures were being used wisely.

Dr. Kara Odom Walker, secretary of the state Department of Health and Social Services, estimated that the CDC plan would cost about $1 million to $2 million annually, but offered no real timeline on how soon it could be put into practice.

Meanwhile, Wilmington witnessed 140 people shot by the end of August — an average of four per week in what may be a record year for bloodshed. In 2013, the year Shabazz was moved to request CDC help, shootings peaked at 154 for the whole year — the city's standing record.

“The CDC gave us a preventative intervention,” said Rita Landgraf, former secretary of the state Department of Health and Social Services who is still working on the CDC plan. “If we were going to remain true to that model, then we would have to be able to look at this data … (and) reach those children identified by the data.”

In 2016, the Markell administration named 25 community members and local leaders to a CDC Community Advisory Council tasked with developing a plan for implementing the CDC's recommendation. The council, led by Shabazz, now president of Wilmington City Council, spent almost a year compiling its own 51-page "Call to Action" report focused on its own recommendations for services to reduce youth violence.

The Delaware report agreed that the city should gather data on at-risk children, but it didn't say where it would find the money, people or software to make it happen.

There's also a legal hurdle to clear: To build the kind of profile the CDC recommended, government agencies and private aid organizations would need to combine a wealth of information. That requires a workaround of federal and state privacy laws, officials said.

“We couldn’t get around the first hurdle,” said Henry Smith, co-chair of the CDC Community Advisory Council created to implement the plan. Delaware lawyers are working to resolve the legal issues, he said.

Yet data aggregation is not as difficult as Delaware is making it, said CDC researcher Steven Sumner.

Last year, he mapped the lives of 421 Wilmington residents arrested for gun crimes between 2009 and 2014, using the same data the state is having trouble obtaining and sharing. He released his findings to demonstrate that identifying at-risk youth is doable using the CDC’s method.

Wilmington also contacted Allegheny County, Pennsylvania — an area encompassing Pittsburgh and some of its suburbs — to see how another metropolitan area overcame the obstacles. While the purpose of Allegheny's data warehouse is different — to help social workers see the complete picture of the families they serve — the bedrock hardware would be similar.

It cost Allegheny County $2.5 million to create a data warehouse in 1999 and another $1.8 million a year to pay staff and maintain the strategy. The price tag could be far less for Wilmington, which has only 5 percent of the population Allegheny serves.

“They (Delaware) can buy the technology and analytics,” said Erin Dalton, a deputy director for the Allegheny office of data analysis, research and evaluation. "They can’t buy the political will.”

This year, the CDC advisory council focused on strengthening existing programs targeting city youth, and on new training for community center staff to recognize trauma.

“This is not going to be done overnight,” Shabazz said. “I think our progress is tremendous.”

The advisory council has been meeting regularly since the spring to identify which youth programs are effective and where they can share resources between government and nonprofit agencies, she said.

"You've never seen such a collaboration to address one issue, ever," Shabazz said.

Still, the violence — largely perpetrated by teen gangs — pushed Delaware's largest city to the most dangerous place in America for kids ages 12 to 17, according to an analysis of Gun Violence Archive per capita data by The News Journal, USA TODAY and the Associated Press.

Today, the situation for teens in Wilmington is actually worse than when the CDC was called.

The last juvenile to lose her life was 16-year-old Tynesia Cephas, gunned down while trying to break up a fight on Wilmington's East Side. Her boyfriend and his family watched as she took her last breath on a row home floor after being shot on Kirkwood Street.

“It’s like death don’t have an age right now, and bullets damn don’t have a name,” said Tyzell Cephas, the girl's 23-year-old brother.

On the same day Cephas died, Delaware State Police Cpl. Stephen Ballard was killed in a Wawa parking lot in the unincorporated community of Bear. The state immediately rallied behind law enforcement and was transfixed on the search for Ballard's killer, who barricaded himself inside his family's Middletown home with scores of police officers outside.

The siege ended 21 hours later when 26-year-old Burgon Sealy Jr. was shot dead after an armored tank began disassembling his family's home.

Weeks later, Ballard's wife, Louise, told those gathered at a CDC Community Advisory Council meeting that her husband would want his death to spur change — not just for his family, but for those suffering from violence statewide.

“My daughter and I are going to be OK, but this community is struggling,” she said at the gathering in Wilmington. "I have the entire state at my fingertips right now. I’ll hold them (accountable) to put the money where their mouth is and cause action. … That’s what my husband would want.”

Cephas’ death drew much less attention. Her killer has not been found, even though the shooter fired among a large crowd.

For many, the killing made April 26 just another day on the city’s streets.

Purzycki and other local leaders stopped by the service at Ezion Fair Baptist Church where Cephas was laid to rest in a gold-trimmed white casket weeks after her death. Trophies marking her achievements for baseball and the Juneteenth Pageant glimmered next to her coffin, adorned with red and white flowers.

“The mayor shook hands, said, ‘I’m sorry for your loss,’” recalled Cephas' brother, Tyzell. “And that’s nice, but I wanna know what paperwork y’all getting ready to file to get this thing rolling … to make sure this never happens again.”

Being raised in a neighborhood racked with poverty, where shootings and drug dealing are an everyday occurrence, and where liquor stores vastly outnumber grocery stores, puts a child at an obvious disadvantage, the CDC said in its report on Wilmington.

Each time a child visits a community center, attends school or gets a summer job, his or her chances at a more stable, successful life improves, according to the CDC.

Conversely, each run-in with the law, each act of violence witnessed, makes it more difficult to reach the child before he becomes a victim of, or engages in, crime that forever alters his future, said the CDC, which has examined only Wilmington's gun violence epidemic among America's cities.

Were the CDC plan implemented, each negative life event would be assigned a score. And if a child's score reached a tipping point, an intervention could be made when the state is called to a child’s home to investigate a report of abuse, when a teenager is arrested, when a student confides in his teacher about a sibling being shot, or when a parent files for unemployment benefits.

It begins with reaching Wilmington teens like a 19-year-old and a 17-year-old, who agreed to speak to The News Journal on the condition that they not be identified — because speaking about the streets, even for those outside of the gang life, could get one killed.

If the CDC plan was in place, these young men may have racked up a high number of points purely because of the ZIP code in which they lived and their life experiences.

The 19-year-old recalls living in Philadelphia’s public housing as a child, while his mother worked two jobs and went to school. His grandmother, who was supposed to be watching him and his siblings, was too strung out on drugs to care for the children, he said.

“I was 9 years old, walking outside to figure out how to get money to feed me, my little brother, and my baby sister,” he said, tears rolling down his cheeks.

A few years later, his mother moved the family to Wilmington to get away from violence and poverty. But life here was no different. In Wilmington, the teen said, he was beaten up his first week of sixth grade.

He was on his way to the cafeteria when a group of classmates punched him repeatedly over a rumor swirling about a girl. He said he sat alone in the lunch room, afraid to tell teachers what had happened.

It was a middle school lesson in the city's no-snitch code — and a reminder that “keeping your head up” to look tough is important in dangerous situations.

The experience made the teen angry – angry enough to join a group of kids he felt could ensure he'd never be beaten up again. His new friendships frightened his mom, who worried the relationships would endanger her other children.

The boy's mother ultimately kicked the teen out of the house. With no place to go, he said he began sleeping in a park. Without a cellphone, it took him weeks to learn his best friend had been caught carrying a gun and was sent to prison.

That ended the 19-year-old's dream of walking through high school graduation with his friend. But he did walk across the stage alone, and today he has a diploma and a part-time job.

Another 17-year-old Wilmington boy who hopes to be the first person in his family to graduate high school also wanted to walk at graduation with his best friend — but his friend was killed by gun violence. And months later, his brother was gunned down on Wilmington’s streets.

He had a searing urge for revenge.

“It makes you want to go out and do something reckless," he said. "But I got a mom here. I got people I’ve got to take care of. It hurts every day, looking at them and knowing my brother is never coming home.”

Had the CDC plan been in place, a caseworker would have intervened in the 19-year-old's life when he got kicked out of his house or beaten up at school. The 17-year-old could have gotten therapy after losing his friend and his brother.

Both boys are determined to get out of Wilmington. Otherwise, they fear they will be pulled into a way of life they want to avoid.

“I'm not about to sit here and be another statistic,” the 19-year-old said.

Added the 17-year-old: “It’s not as easy as everybody thinks it is.”

With no government funding in sight for intervention suggested by the CDC, Shabazz’s strategy is to “re-appropriate dollars” from treatment programs to jump-start the roadmap suggested by the federal agency.

She believes shifting existing dollars toward younger children who have yet to be exposed to trauma would be more successful than trying to change the lives of adults who've already established long criminal histories. But she wouldn’t specify which treatment programs would be cut.

The CDC advisory council earlier this year discussed launching a "Summer for Success Campaign," which council members said would include rallies to kick off programs and free bus passes for youth to get to recreation centers. Those ideas did not come to fruition.

Instead, the advisory council backed already-existing community centers — dubbed "Safe Havens" for the program — and their extended summer hours. The group also endorsed summer learning programs for low-income kids, and trained community center staff in early June on recognizing the signs of children experiencing trauma.

The city renewed its annual program to hire 450 youth for summer jobs at day camps, landscaping businesses and office buildings. Shabazz believed these efforts would help curb teen violence in the city while kids are out of school. Still, five kids under the age of 18 were shot from June through August.

Others on the CDC council have created a plan to link four city schools with community health and social services in New Castle County. The pilot program, modeled after Boston-based City Connects, uses software to create a profile for each student so that the child can continue to receive services even if they transfer between schools and districts.

It could have begun this fall, but it received no state funding.

Training coordinators at each school would cost an estimated $100,000 for the first year, said Matt Swanson, executive chairman of Innovative Schools, an organization that supports new efforts in educating Delaware children. After two years of training staff, it would require just $3,000 to sustain, he said.

"You can really lose a kid when a family gets displaced in the middle of a school year," Swanson said. "Services that they may have found, they may lose when they transfer schools."

Other projects that have been discussed include a youth wellness center modeled after a city re-entry program, and an alternative school suspension program. Many of these efforts require funding, which has yet to be secured.

“We’re still throwing stuff against the wall, and seeing what sticks,” said Parks and Recreation Director Kevin F. Kelley Sr.

On top of looking at programs for youth, Purzycki announced in May a “neighborhood stabilization program” he hopes will turn around the city’s roughest neighborhoods with greater police presence, increased trash pickup, and a crackdown on liquor stores and nuisance properties.

The first neighborhood focus is West Center City, the historic zone from Adams to Tatnall streets, and Fourth to 10th streets.

Few places need help more. Not only is West Center City one of the most violent areas, more than 1 in 10 properties are registered as vacant, and property owners owe the city $1.8 million in unpaid taxes.

Revitalizing the area could have an impact because it is adjacent to the city’s downtown business district and sits against I-95. But similar West Center City efforts dating back to the 1960s have failed to create sustainable change.

Meanwhile, Delaware Attorney Matt Denn pledged $900,000 through the Neighborhood Building Blocks Fund to after-school and summer programs targeting Delaware youth. These efforts include a soccer league for teens in Wilmington's Hilltop neighborhood and a stipend for teens who pick up trash and paint positive messages on boards covering windows of abandoned buildings in West Center City.

And Carney re-established the Family Services Cabinet Council to break down silos that can separate state programs, such as job training, early childhood education, substance abuse treatment and affordable housing.

Yet many caution that while these types of revitalization efforts sound good, agency collaborations and youth programs are useless if the city and state aren’t capable of identifying which children and homes need services the most.

“I’m worried about the kids that aren’t coming [to community centers],” said Paul Calistro, the director of the West End Neighborhood House, a nonprofit in Wilmington’s Little Italy neighborhood. “I’m worried about the corner kids.”

Most kids in the city rarely see run-ins with police as positive, said newly appointed Wilmington police Chief Robert Tracy. He hopes to change that by bringing to Wilmington the Group Violence Intervention strategy used in cities like Chicago and New York.

In reality, only about one-half of 1 percent of Wilmington's population is responsible for the city's gun violence, said David Kennedy, a criminologist at the John Jay College of Criminal Justice in New York. Instead of characterizing these impoverished neighborhoods as violent places dominated by bad people, police need to recognize that many good people live in these communities, said Kennedy, who is helping Tracy implement a new policing strategy.

"What we should recognize about the rest of them is they were born into communities that have historically been treated in ways that have done them incredible damage," Kennedy said.

In Chicago, Tracy used “gang call-ins” to bring together troublemakers and let them hear directly from the people they were hurting: business leaders unable to make money, family members mourning the loss of loved ones and hardworking citizens just trying to scratch out a living.

These meetings served as opportunities for police and social workers to connect with the people that needed them most, Tracy said. If a man said he couldn’t get a job because he didn’t have job training, services were made available. When a woman said she lacked a photo ID, social workers jumped in to fix the problem.

And if the people ignored these opportunities and continued to commit crimes, police pursued arrests. It could be effective in tamping down Wilmington's gang war, the chief said.

"What we want you to do is stay away from the violence, put the guns down, share the message with the people you're with,” Tracy said, “because if the person that commits the crime is someone who is connected to you in some way ... (and) associated with a gang, you're all now responsible."

State prosecutors use a similar approach to hold gang members accountable for the crimes of associates. They used Delaware's gang participation statute in last year’s broad indictment against 29 members of the Only My Brothers gang.

It's an effective tool to get gang members off the streets, said members of the Violent Criminal Enterprises Unit, created by the Attorney General’s Office in August.

"That is the most bang for your buck," said Deputy Attorney General Joseph Grubb. "That is the way to make the streets the most safe, from a prosecutorial angle."

The city does not have a gang unit, however. And Wilmington police Master Sgt. William Schmid wonders if it would benefit from one.

"It's like addiction," said Schmid, who has spent years attending trainings on gang activity. "Until we all acknowledge it and say the four-letter word, gang, it's not going to get better. So let's just accept it and figure out a way to address it."

Many of the city's teens have lost connection with African-American churches that long served as the foundation for Wilmington communities, the Rev. Morton said.

The disconnect has left them without a sense of culture, heritage and values, said Morton, who recalled the programs that fostered his growth as a young man in Wilmington. Until church services and programs become "sexy enough" to get youth through the doors, Morton said the community should not be surprised by the violent ways city youth choose to express themselves.

“Half the time, these kids’ first time in a church is at a funeral,” said Tynesia Cephas’ cousin, Laqueen McDuffie.

At Cephas' funeral, the Rev. Lester Justice urged children to speak out against violence in Wilmington’s streets.

"When we hear about things that are about to occur, we have to come together and say, 'We're not about that life,'" Justice said. "Whether it's at school, at home, in the neighborhood, in the community, we have to say, 'I have a foundation. I want to do better than this.'"

Teens need guidance to overcome constant exposure to violence, poverty and oppression that began when their ancestors were slaves, Morton said.

"Anytime someone continues to experience (violence) and nobody's treating it, in the way for almost 400 years we've not been treating it, we're going to continue getting what we're getting," Morton said. "Even the people pulling the trigger are pulling the trigger because of trauma."

Tracy, state Attorney General Denn and others know that reaching children at the youngest age possible is key to ensuring they never pick up a gun — or end up a victim themselves.

“There’s no age where it’s too young to be thinking about this stuff,” Denn said.

Tracy plans to start calling local schools each morning like he did in Chicago to share information on students whose families may have been impacted by gun violence the night before. Doing so in Delaware is harder due to the fragmented school system, he said, but Tracy hopes to overcome that hurdle.

If nothing is done, community leaders and parents fear teenagers who have already had run-ins with the criminal justice system will constitute another lost generation of young black men.

Jahlil Lewis, the 17-year-old who pleaded guilty as part of the Only My Brothers case, was sentenced to two years in prison and is expected to return home before he turns 18.

His mother, Latisha Jackson, and other parents banded together after their sons were indicted to create a support group called Save Our Sons, and 302 Mothers and Fathers In Action. The parents worry their children will have limited opportunities due to felony gun charges and the no-contact orders put in place to keep them from associating with their childhood friends-turned-accused gang members.

Statistically, the odds are stacked against Jahlil and his friends – because of their age and their criminal records.

A Wilmington teen on community probation is 13 times more likely to be arrested for firearm-related violence than the average child, according to CDC research.

In a sentencing request this summer for Nakeem Bailey, state prosecutors asked for four years behind bars followed by probation for the 16-year-old’s guilty plea. Already, state prosecutor Mark Denney said in a letter to the judge, six of Bailey’s co-defendants were released from prison — and had again committed more crimes.

Bailey also was “among the more brazen OMB members in his display of handguns through photographs and videos,” Denney wrote. These photos depicted Bailey posing with his handgun and pointing it at the camera. Text messages submitted to the judge also show Bailey asking for a $200 handgun with specific requests for the barrel size and magazine capacity.

In late June, Naseem Parks — who pleaded guilty earlier this year to gang participation and gun possession — was charged again with gang participation and rioting after beating up a known member of the rival Shoot to Kill gang in prison. His additional charges, if found guilty, will tack years onto his sentence.

But others, like Jahlil, have plans for their futures.

He told his mom from inside prison that he wants to get his GED, move into his own apartment, work two jobs and buy a car, Latisha Jackson recalled. All of those things would keep him away from the street lifestyle that landed him behind bars.

“One mistake is not his life,” Jackson said. “A lot of (teens) are dying, and I want my kids to live.”

This yearlong investigative project sought to unravel the driving force behind Wilmington's teen violence, an ongoing plague in the city considered most dangerous for children in all of America. Journalists spent more than a year interviewing both the teens affected by the violence and those charged with committing these crimes, state prosecutors, police officers, community members and family members. Reporters attended funerals of children lost to the violence, community meetings and rallies condemning the gunfire, and court hearings of teens and young adults charged with gun violence. Journalists also pored over thousands of pages of court documents, data requests and social media posts to re-create a full account of what prompted a teenage gang war to break out in Delaware's largest city. This three-day series is the result of those efforts.

Brittany Horn is an investigative reporter at The News Journal who has chronicled Wilmington's gun violence and Delaware's struggle with the heroin and opioid epidemic.

Esteban Parra is the solutions and breaking news reporter at The News Journal, where he has worked for more than 20 years covering business, courts, police and Wilmington.

Christina Jedra is Wilmington’s watchdog reporter and focuses on holding elected officials accountable and helping city residents understand how their government works.

Jessica Reyes was the courts and justice reporter at The News Journal, where she documented the state's debate about the death penalty and equal access to justice.

Photos and video used in this series were taken by staff photographers Jennifer Corbett, Suchat Pederson, Daniel Sato, William Bretzger, Damian Giletto and Kyle Grantham.

search_result.title: New Wilmington homes look to curb Delaware's affordable housing ...
search_result.text:
The red brick rowhomes along Bennett Street on Wilmington's East Side stand regally, recently poured concrete steps leading to brightly colored doors.

Residents here have placed flower pots and other greenery next to their stoops, and Ring doorbell cameras hang beside black mailboxes drilled into the new brick.

Across the street, five new homes built with the same materials are nearing completion, though the wood beams that make up front porches have yet to be painted. Still, the fresh timber stands in stark contrast to the wood planks that board up dilapidated homes just blocks away.

search_result.title: Wilmington officials kick off land bank, 'key' to new development
search_result.text:
The demolition of two row homes in northeast Wilmington on Monday marked the kickoff of the city's land bank program to convert vacant properties into affordable housing, public gardens and other developments.

The houses at 50 and 52 E. 22nd St. were bulldozed as part of a collaborative effort between The Wilmington Neighborhood Conservancy Land Bank and Habitat for Humanity. The space and neighboring lots will be used to build six new homes in a neighborhood that struggles with vacancy and violence.

"The land bank is focused on getting vacant properties back into use," said Christian Willauer, executive director of the nonprofit land bank. "This project is an example of the role the land bank can play in working with organizations developing affordable housing."

Without a land bank, Willauer said prospective buyers of abandoned homes would have to buy it at sheriff sale at the cost of the property's accrued debt, including back taxes and water bills. That means a house's price tag could be much more than the property is actually worth, she said, which makes selling it almost impossible.

"If a vacant and abandoned property like this one owes $40,000, it will remain vacant for the rest of our lifetimes," Willauer said.

Under the land bank model, when the city is unable to sell a property at sheriff sale, the property is transferred to the land bank and the city forgives the property's debt, Willauer said.

"What that does is allows the land bank to sell that property at whatever price is going to get it back into use," she said. "The new owner can feel confident that they're starting off with a clean slate. That's really important for promoting investment in our city."

Besides affordable housing, Willauer said possible developments could be a neighbor acquiring a vacant lot for $100 to expand their yard, a group buying or leasing land for a community garden or private developers creating new structures.

RELATED: Wilmington council president hires Rep. Bolden as receptionist

Half of the land bank's 92 properties, which were transferred from the city in October, are scattered single-family residential properties, Willauer said, and will appeal mostly to potential homeowners. The other half are vacant lots.

The land bank can set criteria regarding who buys from their inventory, she said. Priority will be given to buyers who have the vision, commitment and finances to fix a property up.

That's important to residents like 41-year-old Nicole Bowe, who said it's not helpful to a community when affordable housing projects are sold to nonprofits.

"I hope it's all old people moving in on the block," she said.

The Rev. Pastor Sandra Ben, who operates Praying Ground Church on 22nd Street, said the new construction is "a start."

"I think it makes the new neighbors that come in have hope, that it's OK to be here," she said.

By facilitating new uses for abandoned properties, giving opportunities to homebuyers and spurring jobs for local construction workers, the land bank is a key to "how to turn our city around," said City Council President Hanifa Shabazz

"We are going to make sure that everyone is able to feel the benefits of the work of the land bank," she said.

Without redevelopment, blighted homes "put a damper" on new homeowners coming into the neighborhood, said Kevin Smith, the chief executive officer for Habitat for Humanity.

The land bank helps "move projects forward faster, more efficiently, so that we all can win," Smith said.

In the past, when nonprofits like Habitat for Humanity wanted to raze and rebuild a property, they had to cover the acquisition and demolition costs, said Kevin Smith, the chief executive officer for Habitat.

On East 22nd Street, the land bank covered those costs.

"Today is the beginning of a new way of doing business in the city of Wilmington for the nonprofit developers, and we also hope the for-profit developers," he said.

The land bank was assisted by a $1 million grant from the Wilmington-based Barclaycard and a $1.5 million contribution from the city in 2016. Wilmington City Council approved the formation of the land bank in November 2015.

"We believe in the mayor's mission of trying to improve and strengthen our neighborhoods, and it's not through gentrification," said Jocelyn Stewart, senior director of community investment for Barclaycard US.

The land bank's opening project comes as the mayor attempts to rewrite the housing code to make it easier for the city to acquire vacant and neglected homes that would become part of the land bank's inventory.

A reform measure proposed in October would convert housing enforcement from a criminal to a civil matter. Unpaid housing code violations, from broken windows to crumbling foundational walls, would become liens on a property and could eventually proceed to sheriff sale, according to the legislation.

RELATED: Wilmington mayor's anti-blight effort hits roadblock

City residents and council members have expressed concerns that low-income homeowners could have their property taken if they are unable to make repairs. The mayor has insisted that is not his intention to target occupied homes and is working to revise the legislation to reflect that.

The mayor had hoped to have the legislation passed by now so it could be implemented this spring, but his office has not offered an updated timeline since it was delayed by the council in December.

On Monday, Purzycki said the land bank is an example of effective collaboration.

"The city is only going to change when all of our partners get their oars in the water together and pull and row as hard as they can," he said. "And that’s what we’re doing."

Contact Christina Jedra at (302) 324-2837, cjedra@delawareonline.com or on Twitter @ChristinaJedra.

search_result.title: Without grant, plans for more NCCo foot patrols canceled
search_result.text:
New Castle County Police will not expand its foot patrol program as its colonel had hoped because the county decided the costs associated with hiring new officers is too high.

In July, the department applied for a federal COPS grant that would have offered nearly $2 million for new officers.

That grant money was going to be used to hire 15 new officers so Col. Vaughn Bond could place additional senior officers on foot patrols, part of his strategy announced earlier in the year to reinvigorate community-oriented policing.

Now he can't.

There are two patrols in the county walking the streets along the Del. 9 corridor and in Edgemoor as part of Bond's plan. But he wanted more.

The federal grant required matching funds that would have cost the county $1.4million over its three-year life, according to New Castle County Chief Administrative Officer Kathy Jennings. Once the grant expired, they'd have to keep the elevated number of officers.

"That ends up being exponentially more expensive at a time when we're operating in a structural deficit," Jennings said. "We can't fund something we can't afford to pay for over the long term."

The county did announce Wednesday it has accepted a no-strings attached $118,628 grant from the University of Baltimore to hire a coordinator for its Hero Help Program, which offers treatment as an alternative for lesser criminal drug charges.

The 1-year grant will pay the salary for a coordinator, as well as for some of the department's overdose-reversing drugs and program marketing, according to spokeswoman Master Cpl. Heather Carter. The coordinator will be a police department employee.

Withdrawing from the COPS grant won't preclude the county from taking it next year, or hiring officers with other funds in the future, Jennings said.

The decision has not been popular.

The New Castle County Council Public Safety Committee on Dec. 13 took up the issue of police hiring. None of its members spoke in defense of the budget-based decision to turn down the grant.

Council members are angry County Executive Matt Meyer made the grant decision, as they see it, alone. Backing out for the first time in years, they said, unnecessarily left money on the table.

"This was a grave error in judgment," Councilman Jea Street told Jennings and the committee.

Delaware Fraternal Order of Police President Fred Calhoun, himself a New Castle County Police officer, believes costs are a poor argument for missing an opportunity to have more officers.

"I am disappointed that they are not taking this grant. It's a sad day when a person puts the projected or presumed or perceived budgetary issues in place of the welfare and safety of the community and the officers," Calhoun said. "I'm just not sure I buy that as an excuse."

The rank-and-file officers aren't happy either, according to Michael Zielinski, president of FOP Lodge 5.

"They feel the department was on a very good path of progressing forward, and they feel like we're taking a step backward now," Zielinski said. "This was an opportunity for some type of relief."

MORE: New Castle County puts more officers on foot patrols

Since the early 1990s, Community Oriented Policing Services grants have given local police forces almost $15 billion.

The concept of community policing is simple: the better residents know their local officers, the more willingly they would be to cooperate and the less tension there will be with police.

"It's really important in 2017 that police officers get out of their cars," County Executive Matt Meyer said in July. "There's a whole lot of data that shows if you put uniformed officers on the street outside their cars doing old fashioned-style policing, it actually prevents crime."

During Wilmington's mayoral race, when more than a half-dozen candidates were making their pitches to save the city from its violent crime problem, getting officers to leave their cars and walk beats was a constant refrain.

And that's happening now under new city Police Chief Robert Tracy, though he's told residents to give his department time to adjust to a new strategy and warned that results won't be instantly obvious.

"We in policing have done a very bad job of gaining trust in some communities," Tracy told the Wilmington Police Athletic League in July. "It starts with these community meetings, transparency, having a dialogue, being respectful. Respect in the community is going to come back."

Wilmington rejected a similar COPS grant this year for reasons of cost. Mayor Mike Purzycki and Tracy agreed the city is staffed with sufficient officers.

MORE:Purzycki rejects $1.8M grant for 15 police officers

Bond is of a similar mind as Tracy when it comes to community policing, and increasing foot patrols was to be one of his key initiatives.

"I take my direction from the men, the women, the residents of New Castle County," Bond said in July, around the time the department applied for the grant. "When you're going to community meetings and listening to what they want, they're asking for this."

MORE:Girls from Edgemoor Gardens get princess treatment at police ball

County residents still will get community policing, Bond said. He pointed to summertime events like play zones set up for kids and the Police and Princess Ball in October, which Bond said put officers in a position to better know who they serve and vice versa.

"We're not going to stop. We're still going to keep moving forward with the mission of providing quality community policing," Bond said. "Simply because we had to withdraw from this particular grant at this particular time doesn't mean the wheels of the bus stop moving."

MORE:Signs of hope for community policing in Wilmington: Editorial

Those programs have their value, Calhoun said, but when mentioned alongside foot patrols in a conversation on community policing they're little more than "smoke and mirrors."

"The kids that are going to those balls, going to those events, they're not the ones causing you problems," Calhoun said. "That type of community policing is not helping you determine what individuals are causing the crime out on the streets."

The New Castle department has 15 community engagement specialists; four assigned to two-man foot patrols.

It has an authorized strength of 400 officers, up from 385 prior to accepting a 2015 COPS grant. There are 393 officers on the current roster including the current academy class.

There are 22 cadets in academy now, and at the public safety committee meeting, Bond said they represented most of the qualified candidates from about 1,500 applications.

Bond said the average rate of officers leaving the force over the past few years has been about 22 per year.

Next year, more than 60 officers will be eligible for retirement, Bond said. The process of getting a new officer – from placing an advertisement to pinning on a badge – usually takes about a year and a half.

Street grilled Bond and Jennings over these numbers at the committee meeting. His argument was attrition will more than make up for the addition of 15 officers partly funded with grants.

"To your knowledge, has there been a time we have received a grant with comparable requirements where we didn't find it sustainable after a three-year period?" Street asked Bond.

"Not to my knowledge, no," Bond replied.

Fifteen officers were hired through the 2015 COPS grant. It cost the county $1.4 in matching funds over three years, and they're required to continue paying their salaries after the federal money stops in 2018. Jennings said that will add another $1.8million to the budget.

Jennings pointed to an 8 percent decrease in reported county crime this year as proof community policing efforts have been successful. She stressed that future grants may be acceptable to the county administration when the budget can bear the cost.

"You look at where we are right now with the New Castle County Police, and ingrained in their DNA is community policing. They do an outstanding job of it," Jennings said.

Increases in violent crime, especially in Wilmington, and the heroin epidemic are driving up calls for service for New Castle County Paramedics, which Jennings said have not added staff and had to cut $1 million from their budget this year.

"You have a paramedic service that is very stressed," Jennings said. "We really need to make sure we're fiscally responsible and that we take into account saving lives and public safety."

Calhoun said the decision is on the shoulders of the county executive, not the police colonel.

"Any time you turn down money, it's a bad idea," Calhoun said. "It's the aspect of not hiring through attrition, placing the burden of finances on your employees as opposed to raising taxes or really sitting back and looking at what your costs are, figuring out a clean way without affecting your police."

Zielinski doesn't believe the department can accomplish its goals without more officers. He believes crime is down because the department built specialized units, sometimes with federal funds, focused specifically on proactive policing.

"You can't just walk into a community and be able to fix and repair all those problems in a couple of days," Zielinski said. "You can't take resources away from the patrol division, who are responsible for responding to in-progress complaints that are reactive-driven 911 responses, and create other specialized units to combat high-crime or problem areas."

search_result.title: Keep up with the latest on businesses coming and going in Delaware
search_result.text:
We've all driven past a construction site and wondered what it will become.

We hope that this collection of our development coverage will produce answers to some of those questions.

The stories listed below detail the explosion of warehouse space in Delaware, the ceaseless debates between preservation and growth unfolding across the state and some of the most anticipated stores and businesses coming soon.

Consider bookmarking this page as the list will be updated throughout the summer. For more updates, you can join our Facebook group What's Going There in Delaware and subscribe to our free What's Going There in Delaware newsletter.

Wilmington area

• Riverfront to expand east with $100 million mixed-use project: Twenty-five years after Wilmington Mayor Mike Purzycki led the transformation of the city's 100-acre Riverfront from a barren brownfield to a waterfront destination, Purzycki is helping lead the charge to do the same for the other side of the Christina River.

• Incyte continues to expand: The pharmaceutical company filed plans for a large office building on the Wilmington Friends campus. The building will likely be the final piece of their Alapocas campus.

• Another new plan for developing the Brandywine Country Club: The latest proposal involves 300 apartments, 41 single-family homes, 24 townhomes and the possibility of an early education center.

• North Market Street buildings converted to Lincoln Square apartments: Ten buildings on North Market Street are being converted into 39 apartments. Retail space will remain on the ground floor.

• Neighbors oppose latest plan to rehabilitate rotting Gibraltar mansion: The vacant and crumbling former du Pont mansion looms over the city's Highlands neighborhood.

• New Salvation Army Wilmington campus under construction near Chase Fieldhouse: Officials hope to open the new campus, which will have a store, warehouse and living spaces for the needy, on South Market Street this summer.

• Delaware State University takes over Capital One Riverfront building: The new building will headquarter the university's school for graduate, adult and continuing education students, a new partnership with Teen Warehouse's workforce development center and an incubation hub for small businesses with a focus on minority and women-owned companies.

• City wants to make better use of obsolete reservoir: Residents have concerns about the proposals, including the possible destruction of a community garden.

Christiana

• Retail plan scrapped for warehouse project: A 442,000-square-foot warehouse has been proposed at Eagle Run Road west of the Christiana Mall.

• Hobby Lobby coming to Route 273: The national arts and crafts retailer will be to the left of the new Burlington in University Plaza.

• Land cleared for development next to University Plaza on Route 273: Wawa will anchor the project, which is currently under construction.

•New stores, restaurants heading to the Christiana Mall later this year: Lululemon, Hollister and Radcliffe Jewelers are among the new stores coming to Delaware's largest shopping mall.

Kirkwood Highway

• Longtime shopping center wants a facelift: If plans are approved, the Astro shopping center next to the Newark Farmers Market could have a fresh look and a new Wawa.

• Delaware Park offices to be sold: Plans call for six apartment buildings to replace the Delaware Park office building south of Pike Creek Road and All Saints Cemetery. New Castle County amended deed restrictions on the property in May to enable the development.

• Mission BBQ planning second Delaware location: The restaurant is part of a plan filed with New Castle County in January. It would be constructed with a yet to be determined fast food restaurant at the edge of Kirkwood Plaza, according to the plan.

Downtown Newark

• Bonchon and 2SPizza among new businesses coming to Newark: Here's an accounting of what's coming soon downtown, new arrivals you might have missed and development projects in the works.

• 6-story apartment building at Main and Haines Streets: After initially denying the project, Newark City Council in June 2021 approved a plan for 80 apartments, retail space and a public parking garage. It does not appear any site work has begun.

• The Grove at Newark reimagines College Square: The mixed-use complex will have more than 300 apartments and several new shops and restaurants. One of the new tenants is the Louisiana fast food chain Raising Cane's.

• Hotel project at Green Mansion site: A seven-story hotel incorporating the facade of a historic building and a six-story, 48-unit apartment building are under constructed at the center of Newark's Main Street.

• 5-story apartment building to replace decades-old building: After multiple design changes and years of debate, the project received approval in April and will replace the building that is home to Playa Bowls, Tasty Wok and the former Margherita's Pizza.

• Super 8 hotel to become student apartments: The aging hotel next to Grain Craft Bar + Kitchen at the east end of Main Street will be demolished and replaced with an apartment building with a small restaurant on the ground floor.

• Changes coming to office complex: A theater, restaurant and new offices will be built off Paper Mill Road backing up to White Clay Creek and the Newark reservoir.

• Drive to Newark from I-95 could have new hotel: The plan calls for the Red Roof Inn on Route 896 to be demolished and replaced by a Home2Suites by Hilton.

• Plan for office space and apartments on Casho Mill Road: Newark City Council in July 2021 approved a plan for fresh office space and 48 apartments at the corner of Casho Mill and Elkton roads. The three-story building would replace the single-story medical office complex currently at the site, according to the plans.

• Wawa could be coming to corner of Elkton Road: The city annexed the property, which is currently home to Leon's Garden World, in July 2021.

• FinTech building and apartment complex next steps at UD STAR Campus: The opening of UD's FinTech building was delayed from January due to supply chain issues. A residential development led by BPG is also in the works.

Elsewhere in northern New Castle County

• Wegmans leads Barley Mill Plaza redevelopment: The first round of tenants for the new mixed-use center at Lancaster Pike and Centre Road in Greenville also includes First Watch, McGlynns Pub, La Tolteca and Performance Physical Therapy & Fitness.

• Avenue North under construction: The 80-acre property at Concord Pike and Powder Mill Road north of Wilmington will have the city's "one true live-work-play" community, according to its developer.

• Tri-State Mall to be demolished: The Claymont shopping center will be replaced by a 525,000-square-foot warehouse and a small retail building along Naamans Road.

• Amazon facility at Delaware Logistics Park yet to open: Amazon's warehouse at Route 7 and Route 72 has been constructed, but operations have yet to begin. An Amazon spokesperson said there is no timeline for the facility's opening.

• Replacing the Kmart in Pike Creek shopping center: Pike Creek Community Hardware and Edge Fitness are slated to take over the former Kmart.

• First State Crossing reimagines Claymont steel mill: A new train station about a half mile north of Claymont's existing station is expected to open in 2023. Surrounding the station, developers are planning offices, retail, light industrial space and more than 1,000 homes.

• Industrial park could abut I-95 in Bear: New Castle County in December received plans for four warehouse buildings on the north side of Old Baltimore Pike east of Route 72 and south of I-95.

• Water-quality tests manufacturer to build R&D facility in Glasgow: Maryland-based LaMotte Co. is taking over a space in the Pencader Corporate Center off Route 896 previously occupied by Siemens.

• Warehouse planned near New Castle Airport: A roughly 890,000-square-foot warehouse could be built at 650 Churchmans Rd. near New Castle.

• Hotel being built near Delaware Memorial Bridge: A hotel and a travel center, including a Starbucks, are being constructed on a vacant plot behind Royal Farms near the I-295 and Route 9 interchange. The hotel is expected to be completed in 2025.

• Popeyes replacing Denny's on Route 273: A Popeyes is under construction in place of the former Denny's on Route 273 in Ogletown.

• Burger King, Popeyes planned near Elsmere: The Burger King at 300 S. Maryland Avenue near Elsmere will be replaced by a Popeyes and a smaller Burger King under plans filed to New Castle County last year.

• Blue Diamond Park logistics area could be expanded: Amazon may soon have company at the Federal School Lane and Hamburg Road site near New Castle. Plans call for a total of five warehouses at the site, including the e-commerce giant's 1.5-million-square-foot fulfillment center.

• A 'coming soon' sign is outside the Lidl in Bear: Construction of the store has appeared complete since the middle of last year, but the store is "still in the planning phase," according to a company spokesperson.

• Waterfront community being planned in New Castle: The preliminary plans include 451 units, a mix of single-family homes, townhomes and multi-family apartment buildings.

Southern New Castle County

• Developer sues Middletown for right to build apartments: The project in question is Capano Residential's 192-unit apartment complex next to the Dove Run shopping center off Route 299 in Middletown.

• Birdie's to bring golf simulators and family fun to Middletown: The family business includes indoor golf simulators, miniature golf, backyard games and a restaurant and bar.

• Bayberry Town Center adds to Bayberry housing: New Castle County in 2020 approved a shopping center with close to 250,000 square feet of retail space, 145 adjacent townhomes and office space at the Bayberry communities near Middletown.

• Final housing elements of Bayberry housing plan: Two plans call for almost 300 combined homes on both sides of the yet to be constructed Bayberry Town Center as part of the master-planned Bayberry community. The county planning board recommended approval in March.

• Warehouse project replaces plan for hotel, office complex: Together the Scott Run Commerce Center and the Logisticenter at New Castle County could bring six large warehouses to the area near Jamison Corner Road and Route 301. Nearby residents are petitioning against them.

• Delaware's next warehouse hub: Preliminary plans call for four total warehouses totaling about 2.5 million square feet on both sides of Middleneck Road just north of Route 301. The projects, which the state will review in late May, are among several planned on or near Route 301.

• $19 million grant lures Chinese company to Middletown: WuXi AppTec, a Shanghai-based company that develops and manufactures drugs for clients such as AstraZeneca, Pfizer and Roche, is building a manufacturing campus on Industrial Drive.

• Hotel development approved in Middletown: A four-story, 92-room hotel will be built at Middletown Warwick Road and Merrimac Avenue next to The Reserve at Westown apartments.

• Hotel planned off Levels Road in Middletown: The plan, which requires approval, calls for an independently operated hotel called Summerton Suites near the existing Summerton Place apartment complex.

• Middletown YMCA under construction: The new facility, located next to Silver Lake Elementary in Middletown, is expected open by summer 2023.

• RV park and campground on Fort DuPont: An RV park and campground are being built on what was state park land at Fort DuPont in Delaware City.

• The Plaza at Boyds Corner proposed north of Middletown: A homebuilder has proposed an apartment complex with some retail and office space at Boyds Corner Road and Route 13 north of Middletown.

• New Appoquinimink library offers special teen spaces: The library, located at 204 E. Main St. in Middletown, celebrated its grand opening in late June.

Kent County

• Procter & Gamble to be first tenant in Smyrna's Duck Creek Business Campus: The multi-decade project could generate up to 4,000 jobs if fully built out.

• Amazon plans new Delaware solar park in push to use more renewable energy: The company did not say where in Kent County it will be built.

• Boot Barn is bringing its cowboy hats and boots to Dover: The store will be in the Dover Commons shopping center next to the Dover Mall on Route 13.

Sussex County

• Master-planned community gets key approval: More than 1,000 homes, ballfields and trails could one day stretch over 450 acres in Milton. The town in March agreed to annex the site of the proposed project at Sand Hill and Gravel Hill roads.

• Boutique hotel in the works on the Rehoboth Beach boardwalk: The Bellhaven Hotel would be built where Candy Kitchen, the Ice Cream store and Grotto Pizza are located and modeled after the original Bellhaven hotel damaged in the Great Storm of 1962.

• Georgetown Village hotel and The Ponds apartments in development: The projects are being planned behind Georgetown Plaza near Little Street.

• Coral Lakes subdivision denied by Sussex Planning and Zoning Commission: The developer has filed an appeal. The proposal includes 315 homes at Robinsonville Road in Lewes.

• Construction to begin this summer on apartments behind Georgetown Walmart: The development, the Village of College Park, will have 288 apartments and 121 single-family homes. The home construction is expected to start next spring or summer.

• Admiral's Landing to bring 158 townhomes to Georgetown: The project is being planned at Vaughn Road and Ennis Street. Road improvements will be necessary for the development to advance.

• Millsboro is the site of Aldi's eighth Delaware store: The German grocer is coming to Peninsula Crossing between Lowe's and PetSmart.

• Hotel Bethany Beach cuts ribbon on hotel transformation: The renovation targeted the lobby, breakfast area and other aesthetics throughout the hotel.

• Rehoboth Beach hotel to open in 2024: A four-story, 106-room hotel will be built off Coastal Highway.

• Redner's to open in the fall: The long-awaited Lewes-area grocery store will be the company's smaller-format "fresh market" brand.

• Land near Rehoboth Beach to become condos: The owner offered to sell the land to the city of Lewes for $2.5 million. City Council declined the offer.

Like knowing what stores, restaurants and developments are coming and going in Delaware? Join our Facebook group What's Going There in Delaware and subscribe to our free What's Going There in Delaware newsletter.

Contact Brandon Holveck at bholveck@delawareonline.com. Follow him on Twitter @holveck_brandon.

search_result.title: Southbridge Community Services Building opens to homeless ...
search_result.text:
When Air Force veteran Quinncy Moultre stepped into his new apartment this September, it marked the end of a four-year search for stable housing and a return to the "beautiful" worries of “normal life.”

"Now I get to worry about regular things, like running out of milk or doing laundry," said Moultre, 57, who spent two years couch-surfing with family and friends and another two years in a homeless shelter before moving into the Southbridge Community Services Building. "That's what we long for as homeless people. We just want normality."

Creating that sense of normalcy was precisely the goal for Marva Hammond and her 80-year-old father, Charlie Falletta when they established the building in Wilmington’s Southbridge neighborhood in April 2023. They understood that providing affordable apartments alone wasn’t enough – removing everyday barriers was essential for seniors transitioning from homelessness.

The 26-unit building, specifically designed for older homeless individuals with a focus on veterans, includes features to address some of the key factors that contribute to homelessness.

Nine units opened in the first phase in summer 2023, housing several tenants from the Hope Center, including three veterans. Thirteen additional units were completed in August, and three more veterans have since moved in, with more expected by Thanksgiving.

Marva Hammond and her family's focus on homeless veterans stems from a deep appreciation for the sacrifices made by members of the armed services. Hammond is struck by the lack of attention given to the significant challenges faced by veterans returning to civilian life with unresolved mental health issues and barriers to housing.

She expressed dismay at the thought of an 80-year-old veteran forced to take a full-time job to afford housing. "That's just not right. We should be valuing what they did for our country," Hammond said.

According to Hammond, a former housing counselor at Delaware State Housing Authority, the limited support available to veterans often falls short, leaving them struggling to secure adequate housing. Even when they do find a place to live, it often doesn't meet their needs for support that goes beyond financial considerations.

LOOKING FORWARD:How Delaware’s housing authorities are working to boost affordable housing

Creating housing stability goes beyond financial support

The U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development defines "affordable housing" as costing no more than 30% of a resident's gross income. Hammond argues that while it can be helpful as a starting point, this metric doesn't account for real-world circumstances, such as unexpected bills and expenses, or family members who need support.

Hammond emphasized that it is the "simple things" that can make the difference between a tenant succeeding or struggling. According to the housing rights advocate, factoring these realities into the equation sets this affordable housing project apart.

"We're not just providing housing; we're creating a community," Hammond said.

Rent for the 21 units at the Southbridge Community Services Building is subsidized through the federal Housing and Urban Development's housing voucher program, commonly referred to as Section 8. Monthly rents for these units range from $200 to $800, with all utilities included except for Wi-Fi. Solar panels on the building’s roof generate enough electricity to help keep utility costs low.

In addition to providing affordable rents, Hammond and her family work to address minor obstacles that can lead to daily frustrations.

Tenants receive assistance with basic tasks, such as using the laundry machines, a microwave or the secure entry system, which can help maintain resident stability.

To make Wi-Fi setup easier, the Southbridge Community Services Building contracts with a local provider that offers Wi-Fi and straightforward access to customer service, rather than one that offers a complex menu of options.

The building is pet-friendly with no extra fees, recognizing that companionship is vital for seniors living alone. "Having something to take care of, to be accountable for, to love you – that can make the difference in somebody's life," Hammond said.

For Moultre, it's the peaceful environment and Southbridge neighborhood that makes the biggest difference. "It offered everything I needed in a home," he said.

Small-scale projects may also be a part of the solution

Challenging the notion that only large-scale developments can address housing needs, the Southbridge Community Services Building offers several key lessons for affordable housing development. It starts with community engagement.

"Developers need to be intentional," Hammond said.

Hammond acknowledged that not everyone has the resources to build a 26-unit, $3 million affordable housing complex. She believes smaller efforts like partnering with an organization or developer to buy a single house and make it affordable can make a difference.

Beyond individual projects, Hammond emphasized the need for broader, systemic support of affordable housing initiatives. She encourages housing advocates to engage with policymakers to shape program development and funding allocations.

As Delaware’s homelessness crisis grows, the Southbridge Community Services Building stands as an example of the affordable housing that many, like Moultre, are striving to access.

You can contact Anitra Johnson at ajohnson@delawareonline.com.

search_result.title: Wilmington's Parks and Rec deputy director turns focus to city youth
search_result.text:
Raised in Southbridge, the new deputy director of Wilmington’s Parks and Recreation Department has been on the job for only one month but says she is already using her previous experience working with youth and her love for the community to make an impact.

Melody Phillips, 42, joined the department on August 1. Her role oversees the day-to-day operations of Wilmington’s city parks, as well as supervising recreation centers.

Phillips has worked in the programming industry for more than a decade. Most recently, she was the director at The Warehouse, a community hub for teenagers to access social and recreational activities in Northeast Wilmington.

Phillips has also worked as a program manager at Delaware Technical Community College, where she helped build a GED and career pathway program for struggling youth between the ages of 16 to 24.

“The program was really successful," Phillips said. "We had a 72% completion rate and the requirement from the state was 67%.”

FOR SUBSCRIBERS:'Teen Warehouse' to provide opportunities for young people in Wilmington's Riverside neighborhood

As a native of the Southbridge neighborhood, Phillips developed a passion for serving youth and families in the Wilmington area. She prioritizes building communities and enhancing social justice initiatives.

“Southbridge is home and that's where I grew up," Phillips said. "People will often hear me rep Southbridge frequently because I still have a heart for it."

In addition to her programming background, Phillips started her own consulting firm in an effort to spark community action through grant writing and designed initiatives. She is also enrolled in the Chicago School of Professional Psychology's doctorate program and is in the process of completing her dissertation on co-developed youth and adult leadership models.

Delaware Online/The News Journal caught up with Phillips to learn about her plans for the department and what she hopes to accomplish.

The following Q&A has been edited for length and clarity:

Q: How did you become interested in the position and why do you want to help lead the department?

A: I believe young people need to be in spaces and places where we can really elevate them to lead and so anytime I have an opportunity to do that — it’s a good day. Ironically enough after I resigned from the Teen Warehouse to start my own consulting firm, (Parks and Recreation) Director (Ian) Smith reached out to me to do an assessment of his leadership team. I met with them, did observations, conducted individual interviews to help understand their inner workings. Through this process, I also informed them of different ways that the Willam "Hicks" Anderson Community Center could grow from a program standpoint.

Q: How has your previous background in programming and consulting prepared you for this position?

A: I’ve only been with this team for a few weeks now but I’m already tapping into a lot of that experience. For example, my community service work — because I’ve made some wonderful connections with both large and small grassroots and non-profits from across the city, I was able to reach out to a bunch of different partners and have them actively engage with a recent open house that we had. Having built those relationships and having that experience of running the Team Warehouse has helped me prepare.

Q: What are some goals that you have for Wilmington?

A: Increasing recreation and another goal is really developing a youth leadership program at the Hicks Anderson Community Center and bridging the gap between our senior centers on the first floor and the programs that run on the main level of the building, so that way our seniors could feel more included — we really want to make sure that they are being involved in the activities. This would also include doing a program where some of our young people interact with the seniors and help them understand the nuances of technology, which will help the digital divide that some of our seniors experience. I also heard from a lot of young people that they would love to have a music production studio at Hicks Anderson.

Q: Are there any glaring issues in Wilmington that you want to address?

A: One of the things that we identified especially that there are a lot of “food deserts” around the city — meaning there isn’t a local grocery store that is readily accessible. So one of the ideas that we have is expanding the community refrigerators that are popping up in the city. We are currently having conversations with the nonprofit, Planting to Feed, to potentially launch a community refrigerator in front of Hicks Community Center.

Q: Are there any specific programs that you want to bring to community centers or parks around Wilmington?

A: I think a priority will be making sure that the Wilmington area knows about the programs that are already available and having constant communication between all the community centers — all of them do an excellent job by offering programs to both youths and adults and even 12 and under. I think some sort of interactive calendar where we can place events of each others around the city would really impact how we can get more community members to support these events throughout the entire city.
